                <li id="story-id-1248069044202"><article class="story theme-summary" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
    <div class="story-body">
        <a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/07/dining/davelle-review-lower-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
            <div class="story-meta">
                <h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
                    Davelle                </h2>
                <ul class="review-meta-menu">
                                        <li class="critics-pick">
                        <i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
                        <span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
                    </li>
                                                                                <li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese</li>
                                                            <li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>
                                                            <li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>
                                    </ul>
                <p class="summary" itemprop="description">By day, this tiny restaurant with walls of chipped paint is a kissaten (coffee shop), devoted to breakfasts of shokupan — Japanese milk bread, unapologetically white — and lunches of deeply marine spaghetti, littered with uni (sea urchin) and mentaiko (spicy cod roe). At night, it turns into an izakaya, serving oden from a broth as old as the restaurant.</p>
                                    <p class="byline" itemprop="author">By <span class="author-name">Ligaya Mishan</span></p>
                            </div><!-- close story-meta -->
                            <div class="wide-thumb">
                    <img role="presentation" src="https://static.nytimes.com/images/2018/06/13/dining/13hungry-ss1/13hungry-ss1-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
                </div><!-- close wide-thumb -->
                    </a>
    </div><!-- close story-body -->
    <footer class="story-footer">
        <time class="dateline" datetime="2018-06-07" itemprop="dateModified" content="2018-06-07">June 7, 2018</time>
        <ul class="story-action-menu">
            <li>
                <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/07/dining/davelle-review-lower-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
            </li>
                    </ul>
    </footer>
</article>
</li>
                <li id="story-id-1248069044201"><article class="story theme-summary" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
    <div class="story-body">
        <a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/31/dining/lahi-elmhurst-queens-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
            <div class="story-meta">
                <h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
                    Lahi                </h2>
                <ul class="review-meta-menu">
                                                                                <li itemprop="servesCuisine">Philippine</li>
                                                            <li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>
                                                            <li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Elmhurst</li>
                                    </ul>
                <p class="summary" itemprop="description">Henry Matibag, the chef of this modest Filipino restaurant, and his wife, Agnes, were childhood sweethearts in the Philippines who lost touch and reunited in New York years later.</p>
                                    <p class="byline" itemprop="author">By <span class="author-name">Ligaya Mishan</span></p>
                            </div><!-- close story-meta -->
                            <div class="wide-thumb">
                    <img role="presentation" src="https://static.nytimes.com/images/2018/06/06/dining/06hungry-ss1/06hungry-ss1-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
                </div><!-- close wide-thumb -->
                    </a>
    </div><!-- close story-body -->
    <footer class="story-footer">
        <time class="dateline" datetime="2018-05-31" itemprop="dateModified" content="2018-05-31">May 31, 2018</time>

                <li id="story-id-1248069044200"><article class="story theme-summary" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
    <div class="story-body">
        <a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/29/dining/don-angie-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
            <div class="story-meta">
                <h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
                    Don Angie                </h2>
                <ul class="review-meta-menu">
                                        <li class="critics-pick">
                        <i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
                        <span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
                    </li>
                                                            <li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
                        <meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
                        <meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
                        <meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">
                                                <span class="visually-hidden">2 stars</span>
                                                <i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i> <i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>                     </li>
                                                            <li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Italian</li>
                                                            <li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>
                                                            <li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">West Village</li>
                                    </ul>
                <p class="summary" itemprop="description">Artful versions of chicken scarpariello, antipasto salad and braciole; mirrors with gold pinstripes; smart modern cocktails at a bar made of polished marble the color of beef carpaccio; a California sangiovese in a straw-covered Chianti bottle: There is hope for the red-sauce renaissance, after all.</p>
                                    <p class="byline" itemprop="author">By <span class="author-name">Pete Wells</span></p>
                            </div><!-- close story-meta -->
                            <div class="wide-thumb">
                    <img role="presentation" src="https://static.nytimes.com/images/2018/05/30/dining/30rest-ss1/30rest-ss1-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
                </div><!-- close wide-thumb -->
                    </a>
    </div><!-- close story-body -->
    <footer class="story-footer">
        <time class="dateline" datetime="2018-05-29" itemprop="dateModified" content="2018-05-29">May 29, 2018</time>

            <li>
                <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/29/dining/don-angie-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
            </li>

                <li id="story-id-1248069044199"><article class="story theme-summary" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
    <div class="story-body">
        <a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/24/dining/bar-patron-rockpool-review-sydney.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
            <div class="story-meta">
                <h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
                    Bar Patrón by Rockpool                </h2>
                <ul class="review-meta-menu">
                                                                                <li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican</li>
                                                            <li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>
                                                            <li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Circular Quay</li>
                                    </ul>
                <p class="summary" itemprop="description">Bar Patrón, in Sydney’s Circular Quay, has been marketed as the maturation of Mexican food in Australia — put in a fine dining context and given the respect it deserves. But the restaurant is mostly notable because it is a collaboration between the Patron tequila brand and the Rockpool Dining Group, an Australian behemoth lead by Neil Perry, one of the country’s most famous chefs.</p>
                                    <p class="byline" itemprop="author">By <span class="author-name">Besha Rodell</span></p>
                            </div><!-- close story-meta -->
                            <div class="wide-thumb">
                    <img role="presentation" src="https://static.nytimes.com/images/2018/05/24/dining/24fare-ss1/24fare-ss1-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
                </div><!-- close wide-thumb -->
                    </a>
    </div><!-- close story-body -->
    <footer class="story-footer">
        <time class="dateline" datetime="2018-05-24" itemprop="dateModified" content="2018-05-24">May 24, 2018</time>
        <ul class="story-action-menu">
            <li>
                <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/24/dining/bar-patron-rockpool-review-sydney.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
            </li>
                        <li>
                <a class="reserve-table" href="https://www.dimmi.com.au/restaurant/bar-patron-by-rockpool" target="_blank" title="Reserve a Table">Reserve a Table</a>

                <li id="story-id-1248069044196"><article class="story theme-summary" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">

            <div class="story-meta">
                <h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
                    Em                </h2>
                <ul class="review-meta-menu">
                                        <li class="critics-pick">
                        <i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
                        <span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
                    </li>
                                                                                <li itemprop="servesCuisine">Vietnamese</li>
                                                            <li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>
                                                            <li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Bensonhurst</li>
                                    </ul>
                <p class="summary" itemprop="description">The brief menu at this bright, trim restaurant includes pho, classic and unorthodox versions of banh mi, and voluptuous mango and avocado shakes, thickened with sweetened condensed milk and house-made yogurt.</p>
                                    <p class="byline" itemprop="author">By <span class="author-name">Ligaya Mishan</span></p>
                            </div><!-- close story-meta -->

                <li id="story-id-1248069044195"><article class="story theme-summary" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
    <div class="story-body">
        <a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/15/dining/simon-and-the-whale-restaurant-review-flatiron.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
            <div class="story-meta">
                <h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
                    Simon &amp; the Whale                </h2>
                <ul class="review-meta-menu">
                                        <li class="critics-pick">
                        <i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
                        <span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
                    </li>
                                                            <li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
                        <meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
                        <meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
                        <meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">
                                                <span class="visually-hidden">2 stars</span>
                                                <i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i> <i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>                     </li>
                                                            <li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>
                                                            <li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>
                                                            <li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Flatiron</li>
                                    </ul>
                <p class="summary" itemprop="description">Gabe Stulman, who specializes in building miniature downtown hangouts, has applied his techniques to a large hotel restaurant. As usual, the cocktails are excellent. the service enthusiastic and the food more interesting that it has to be.</p>
                                    <p class="byline" itemprop="author">By <span class="author-name">Pete Wells</span></p>

                <li id="story-id-1248069044193"><article class="story theme-summary" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
    <div class="story-body">
        <a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/08/dining/soogil-review-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
            <div class="story-meta">
                <h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
                    Soogil                </h2>
                <ul class="review-meta-menu">
                                        <li class="critics-pick">
                        <i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
                        <span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
                    </li>
                                                            <li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
                        <meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
                        <meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
                        <meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">
                                                <span class="visually-hidden">2 stars</span>
                                                <i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i> <i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>                     </li>
                                                            <li itemprop="servesCuisine">Korean</li>
                                                            <li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>
                                                            <li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>
                                    </ul>
                <p class="summary" itemprop="description">You can almost draw a straight line from Soogil Lim’s resume to what’s on the table at his four-month-old restaurant in the East Village, Soogil. At Hanjan, where he cooked for four years, he learned how to rework Korean food into appealing, contemporary, small plates.</p>
                                    <p class="byline" itemprop="author">By <span class="author-name">Pete Wells</span></p>
                            </div><!-- close story-meta -->
                            <div class="wide-thumb">
                    <img role="presentation" src="https://static.nytimes.com/images/2018/05/09/dining/09REST-slide-E1QE/09REST-slide-E1QE-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
                </div><!-- close wide-thumb -->
                    </a>
    </div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044192-1">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/03/dining/bab-marrakech-review-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Bab Marrakech
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Moroccan</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Bay Ridge</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Ismail Bourrich and his wife, Bouchra Salmi, natives of Morocco, run this comfortable, unpretentious restaurant with the chef Malika Hakmoune in the kitchen. Hers is an art of expansive comfort, materializing in great plates of meat, ample tagines revealed with the whisking away of a funneled lid and, on Fridays only, couscous.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/05/09/dining/09HUNGRY-slide-YFYP/09HUNGRY-slide-YFYP-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044191">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/01/dining/la-mercerie-review-soho.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
La Mercerie
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">SoHo</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
In this elegant corner cafe, Marie-Aude Rose cooks as if the fate of the planet depended on the tenderness of her cheese omelets, the judiciousness of her vinaigrettes, the airy spaces in her croissants and the crackle of the buckwheat in her savory crepes.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/05/02/dining/DIN-slide-IUX0/DIN-slide-IUX0-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044190">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/26/dining/re-store-review-australia.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Re Store
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Deli, Italian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Northbridge</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The Re Store in Perth’s Northbridge neighborhood is most often cited as the originator of the continental roll (or the conti roll, or simply: the roll) – in the 1950s, working men who frequented the store would buy crusty rolls and stuff them with meats and cheese purchased from the deli. And so John Re, the store’s owner, took over sandwich making duties from his customers.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Besha Rodell
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/04/26/dining/26FARE-slide-1ZI2/26FARE-slide-1ZI2-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2018-04-26T12:52:50">April 26, 2018</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/26/dining/re-store-review-australia.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>

<li id="story-id-1248069044185">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/26/dining/ludas-dumplings-review-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Luda’s Dumplings
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Russian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Sheepshead Bay</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this small, decidedly modern pelmeni shop with a few stools along a counter, dumplings are made with thoughtfully chosen ingredients — organic flour; grass-fed beef and pastured pork — and cooked to order, then glossed with drops of clarified butter
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044184">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/19/dining/ho-foods-review-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Ho Foods
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Taiwanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Richard Ho, the chef of this exceedingly tiny storefront devoted to Taiwanese beef noodle soup, grew up in the San Gabriel Valley east of Los Angeles, in an area once known as Xiao (Little) Taipei. His soup, made with a stock of cow hooves and beef shin bones simmered for a day and a night, is notably holistic, neither frankly carnal nor purely herbaceous but somewhere more intriguingly in between.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

<li id="story-id-1248069044183">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Gauge
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Australian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Brisbane</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Brisbane’s Gauge is the work of a group of young and passionate dudes: owner Jerome Batten, chefs Cormac Bradfield and Phil Merchant, and front of house manager Jack Brooks. The restaurant serves avocado toast and bacon sandwiches with barbecue sauce during the day, but at night the food takes a serious turn, with various options that include two-, three- and seven-course menus.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Besha Rodell
</span>

Ejen
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

</ul>

<li id="story-id-1248069044177-2">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/15/dining/soi-38-review-melbourne-thai.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Soi 38
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Thai</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Melbourne</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Nestled in the middle of the ground floor of a Melbourne Central Business District parking garage, right next to the elevators, Soi 38 is a colorful nook of a restaurant, serving bowls of Thai noodles for $10 a pop at lunchtime only, six days a week.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Besha Rodell
</span>

<div class="wide-thumb">

</a>

<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2018-03-15T13:16:02">March 15, 2018</time>

<li id="story-id-1248069044176">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/15/dining/junebaby-review-seattle-black-southern-food.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
JuneBaby
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Southern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Ravenna</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Much of the huge edifice of Southern cuisine was built by black cooks. The chef Edouardo Jordan celebrates their contribution at JuneBaby, with particular attention to chitterlings and other home-cooked dishes rarely seen in restaurants that have cocktail menus and wine lists.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By

</h2>

<li class="critics-pick">

<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
L’Atelier de Joël Robuchon
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chelsea</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Joël Robuchon’s experiment in making people sit at counters for small tastes of his excruciatingly precise food was radical when he introduced it in Paris in 2003. In modern New York it is anything but shocking, and while the standards are as high as ever, new sensations are rare.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069044166-3">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/13/dining/hwa-yuan-szechuan-review-chinese-food.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Hwa Yuan Szechuan
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chinatown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
In 1968, a chef named Shorty Tang opened a restaurant on East Broadway, Hwa Yuan Szechuan Inn, where among other renditions of Sichuanese food he made cold sesame noodles that would lodge themselves in the memories of generations of New Yorkers and be imitated, often pitiably, by takeout cooks all over town. Decades after it closed, two of his descendants have reopened it on the site of the original. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/02/14/dining/14REST-slide-ZR9U/14REST-slide-ZR9U-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2018-02-13T12:24:12">Feb. 13, 2018</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/13/dining/hwa-yuan-szechuan-review-chinese-food.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

<li>
<a class="reserve-table" href="https://resy.com/cities/ny/hwa-yuan-szechuan?utm_source=nyt&amp;utm_medium=restoprofile&amp;utm_campaign=affiliates&amp;aff_id=c1fe784" target="_blank" title="Reserve a Table">Reserve a Table</a>
</li>

</ul>

<li id="story-id-1248069044165">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/08/dining/kebab-empire-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Kebab Empire
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian, Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown West</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Kudret Yakup, the owner, grew up in the desert town of Kashgar, on the old Silk Road in the far western borderlands of China; after graduating from Harvard, he started what may be the first American franchise-in-the-making to showcase the food of his people, the Uighurs, a Turkic-speaking and mostly Muslim minority in China and in Central Asia.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044164">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/06/dining/grant-achatz-office-aviary-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Aviary NYC, The Office NYC
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Upper West Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Grant Achatz’s two path-breaking cocktail lounges in Chicago try to adapt themselves to life in a New York luxury hotel, with mixed results.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells

</ul>

<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/04/dining/saint-peter-review-seafood-sydney.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Saint Peter
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Australian, Seafood</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Paddington, Australia</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Sydney’s Saint Peter restaurant, chef Josh Niland takes the bro-chef love of offal and elegantly applies it to aquatic ingredients. The menu might include toast piled with the liver of John Dory, or chips made from the eyeball of a different kind of Dory.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Besha Rodell
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/01/04/dining/04FARE-slide-1P08/04FARE-slide-1P08-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2018-01-04T12:41:48">Jan. 4, 2018</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/04/dining/saint-peter-review-seafood-sydney.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>

<li id="story-id-1248069044151">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/26/dining/the-loyal-review-nyc.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Loyal
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenwich Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The Loyal looks like an update of a 1950s nightclub, with leather booths and banquettes under ceiling fans. John Fraser’s crowded menu is something of a free-for-all, borrowing from brasseries, trattorias and mainstream American taverns and ice cream parlors.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/12/27/dining/27REST-LOYAL-slide-WBN2/27REST-LOYAL-slide-WBN2-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044150">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/21/dining/agrarian-kitchen-review-new-norfolk-tasmania.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Agrarian Kitchen Eatery &amp; Store
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Australian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">New Norfolk</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Located in New Norfolk, a town in the Derwent Valley 40 minutes outside of Hobart, the Agrarian Kitchen is a pioneer in Tasmania’s emerging food and drink scene. But there’s a stark, almost shocking contrast between Agrarian Kitchen and its setting: the restaurant makes its home in one wing of an abandoned mental hospital.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Besha Rodell
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Sendok Garpu
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Indonesian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Indooroopilly, Australia</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Sendok Garpu, which means “spoon and fork” in Indonesian, began as a stall in an industrial park parking lot. Its second location, in a suburb on the other side of Brisbane, is a large restaurant decorated in dark wood, Indonesian fabrics and leafy potted plants, and serves specialties from all over Indonesia.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Besha Rodell
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044146-5">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/05/dining/jeju-noodle-bar-review-korean-ramen.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Jeju Noodle Bar
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Korean</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">West Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The inspiration is Korean ramen. This almost always means instant, but not here. All of Jeju Noodle Bar’s broths have the body and texture that come with boiling and skimming for hours over an abundance of meat and bones.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/12/06/dining/06REST-4/06REST-JEJU-slide-UV9M-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">

<li id="story-id-1248069044145">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/30/dining/khao-nom-review-thai-desserts-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Khao Nom
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Southeast Asian, Thai</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Elmhurst</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Sopon Kosalanan, a native of Chantaburi in eastern Thailand, runs both Khao Kang, a steam-table restaurant notable for the uncompromising sourness and heat of its curries, and this bright, modern cafe around the corner, devoted to Thai snacks and desserts that favor surprise and evanescence over sweetness.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Pazar Food Collective
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican, Turkish</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Canterbury, Australia</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Pazar Food Collective, a neighborhood restaurant in the South-western Sydney suburb of Canterbury, serves food inspired by both Turkey and Mexico — the amalgamation of owner Attila Yilmaz’s culinary experiences.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Besha Rodell
</span>

</a>

<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-11-22T14:46:24">Nov. 22, 2017</time>

<li id="story-id-1248069044141">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/16/dining/abuqir-review-seafood-restaurant-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
AbuQir Seafood
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Middle Eastern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Astoria</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
AbuQir takes its name from a fishing village on the eastern outskirts of Alexandria, Egypt. And as they do at the makeshift restaurants that line the beach there, the menu is unwritten: You point to what you want among the fish, shrimp and calamari arrayed on ice, and the genial host, who doubles as a cook and waiter, asks, “How do you want it?”
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Cote
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Korean</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Flatiron</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The highlight of this modern Korean barbecue restaurant is the “butcher’s feast,” a set menu with fluffy steamed eggs in a pot, two fundamental Korean stews, pickles, lettuce and, at the center of it all, a dealer’s choice of four cuts of beef. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069044136-6">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Margarita’s
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Latin American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Longwood</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Margarita Brito’s pastelillos (cousins to empanadas, but flakier) and alcapurrias (pockets of fried dough made from mashed green bananas and plantains) are beloved in this predominantly Latino neighborhood, where she and her mother, immigrants from the Dominican Republic, ran a food truck for years.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069044135">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/26/dining/federal-doma-cafe-review-japanese-food-nsw-australia.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Federal Doma Cafe
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Federal, New South Wales, Australia</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Federal Doma Cafe represents much of what is fascinating about the current food scene in Australia: the spread of vibrant and creative cooking to rural areas; the stunning ambition and quality found in the country’s cafes; and perhaps most important, the ways in which immigrant foodways are changing as they mix with this culinary landscape.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Besha Rodell
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044134">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/26/dining/boishakhi-review-bangladeshi-restaurant-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Boishakhi
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Bangladeshi</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Astoria</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this low-key Bangladeshi cafeteria, the steam table is a vision of food without end. The chef, Shahara Khan, has roots in Narsingdi, just outside of Dhaka, the Bangladeshi capital, and the flavors are distinct to the Bay of Bengal.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069044133">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/19/dining/yuan-review-chinese-noodles-nyc.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Yuan
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Ignore the other dishes: the specialty here is Guilin mi fen (rice noodles), from China’s southern Guangxi Province, a rarity in New York. The bowl comes crowded with deep-fried soybeans, pickled long beans, thin panels of pliant beef, bacon-like pork belly and a littering of chile flakes, scallion and torn cilantro. The noodles wait below, as thick as spaghetti, slippery but still springy.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/10/25/dining/25HUNGRY-YUAN-slide-VLMH/25HUNGRY-YUAN-slide-VLMH-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-10-19T00:00:00">Oct. 19, 2017</time>

<li id="story-id-1248069044132">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/17/dining/the-pool-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Pool
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Seafood</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Under the hand of Rich Torrisi, the Pool serves seafood with a contemporary outlook. Mr. Torrisi’s approach is to be lavish with punctiliously cared-for seafood and to outfit it sparingly.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-10-17T00:00:00">Oct. 17, 2017</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Benyam
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Ethiopian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Harlem</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Benyam, traditional Ethiopian food is served in a glass-fronted dining room crowded with street art, speaking to a coolly cosmopolitan modern day.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

Public Kitchen
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Chinese, Italian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044129">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/05/dining/my-cuban-spot-review-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
My Cuban Spot
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Caribbean, Latin American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Gowanus</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Louie Estrada, who was born in Miami, modeled this slip of a storefront after the cafeterías and ventanitas (coffee windows) of Calle Ocho in Little Havana. The food is comfortingly straightforward and inspired by the cooking of his grandmother, who left Cuba in the early 1960s.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/10/11/dining/11HUNGRY-slide-L7TE/11HUNGRY-slide-L7TE-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

<li id="story-id-1248069044122">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/26/dining/cervos-review-restaurant.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Cervo’s
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Portuguese, Seafood, Spanish</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This restaurant on the east end of Canal Street doesn’t call itself a wine bar, but it does a good impersonation of one. The food, mostly seafood, is casual and unstudied, allowing you to focus on the list of Spanish and Portuguese wines, with few familiar names.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044121">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/21/dining/wus-wonton-king-review-chinese-restaurant-nyc.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Wu’s Wonton King
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
To passers-by, Wu’s Wonton King might look like just another Cantonese restaurant, with ducks and suckling pigs gleaming from hooks in the window and eels necking in a tank. But the menu — encyclopedic in breadth, minimalist in detail — fulfills its promises, delivering whole live seafood, barbecued meats with bronzed, crackling skin and impeccable won tons in cloudy, long-simmered pork-bone broth.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/09/27/dining/27HUNGRY-WU-slide-C20E/27HUNGRY-WU-slide-C20E-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-09-21T00:00:00">Sept. 21, 2017</time>

<li>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Tradita
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Eastern European </li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Norwood</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
While the looming wood-fired pizza oven in the corner turns out respectable pies, the Albanian snacks — rugged sausages, flaky burek and layered savory cakes seamed with cheese — are what comfort.
</p>

Ligaya Mishan

<li id="story-id-1248069044119">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/12/dining/razza-pizza-review-jersey-city.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Razza
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Pizza</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Razza is one of the few pizzerias that excel at both the dough and the toppings. The pizza’s crust has the texture and flavor of naturally leavened bread right from the oven, and it is baked under local ingredients so distinctive that each time you eat there, you might learn something you didn’t know about New Jersey.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/09/13/dining/13REST-Razza-slide-9NCN/13REST-Razza-slide-9NCN-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-09-12T00:00:00">Sept. 12, 2017</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>

<li id="story-id-1248069044118">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/07/dining/prontito-review-colombian-food-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Prontito
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Latin American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Elmhurst</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This Colombian restaurant turns out some of New York’s finest cholados, towers of pulverized ice and tropical fruit half-melting, half-swimming in lechera (condensed milk), summoning every gradation of sweetness.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Bikash Kharel, who grew up half in Nepal, half in Ridgewood, Queens, opened While in Kathmandu as a sequel of sorts to his parents’ more bluntly named Nepalese Indian Restaurant down the street.

<li id="story-id-1248069044116">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/24/dining/samis-kabab-house-review-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Sami’s Kabab House
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Afghan</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Astoria</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Sami Zaman, an immigrant from Kabul, Afghanistan, spent years selling coffee from a pushcart in Midtown Manhattan. Here, he has transformed an industrial space with wine-dark carpets and embossed ceiling tiles, and unfussy dishes — shaggy dumplings; simple, gratifying arrangements of meat — that reflect his half-Uzbek, half-Tajik heritage.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044115-8">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/22/dining/the-grill-review-midtown.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Grill
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
In what used to be the Grill Room of the Four Seasons, The Grill comes very close to being the kind of restaurant many New Yorkers imagined in this space all along. The Grill is confident, theatrical, retro, unsentimental, sharp and New Yorky.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044114">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/17/dining/factory-tamal-review-mexican-food.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Factory Tamal
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Nixtamalization, the ancient Mayan method of preparing corn to make masa (dough), is so time-intensive a process that many Mexican restaurants in New York get by with premade nixtamalized corn flour instead. But at this small, mostly takeout shop, Fernando Lopez follows the ancient Mayan way.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

<li id="story-id-1248069044109">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Atla
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>

<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">NoHo</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Having proved at Cosme that they have original things to say about Mexican cuisine, Enrique Olvera and Daniela Soto-Innes are set free to serve Mexican food at Atla that New Yorkers might want to eat every day, which is not to say that this is the everyday cooking of Mexico.

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By

Pete Wells
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069044108">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/20/dining/969-nyc-coffee-review-japanese-food.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
969 NYC Coffee
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Jackson Heights</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Inside this small Japanese half-grocery, half-snack shop just off Roosevelt Avenue, cases and shelves are stocked with honey butter chips and Hello Kitty mango marshmallows, cans of royal milk tea and boxes of pre-made sushi heavy on avocado and spicy mayonnaise. Behind the counter, Oda Mitsumine makes onigiri (rice balls) shaped like hearts and keeps vigil on a simmering pot of milky tonkotsu ramen broth.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/07/26/dining/26HUNGRY-969CAFE-slide-Y59C/26HUNGRY-969CAFE-slide-Y59C-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-07-20T00:00:00">July 20, 2017</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/20/dining/969-nyc-coffee-review-japanese-food.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044106">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/13/dining/vietnamese-restaurant-nyc-hanoi-house-madame-vo-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Hanoi House
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Vietnamese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The first spoonful of Hanoi-style pho bac — darker and funkier than its sweet southern cousin — is a shock, the broth a living thing, drawn from a pot crowded with bones and kept seething through the night. The chef, John Nguyen, was born in Saigon just before the city fell, the son of a northerner and a southerner, and in a handful of vivid, exacting dishes he evokes the country’s breadth. The dining room seems to rest in an eternal dusk, with antique shutters and patterned tile casting back to French colonial times.  
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/07/19/dining/19HUNGRY-HANOI-slide-UPNE/19HUNGRY-HANOI-slide-UPNE-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-07-13T00:00:00">July 13, 2017</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/13/dining/vietnamese-restaurant-nyc-hanoi-house-madame-vo-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>
</li>
<li id="story-id-1248069044107">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/13/dining/vietnamese-restaurant-nyc-hanoi-house-madame-vo-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Madame Vo
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Vietnamese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Jimmy Ly, the chef, grew up in Astoria, Queens; his wife, Yen Vo — Madame Vo to you — was born in a refugee camp in Thailand and settled on the Mississippi Gulf Coast. At this bright, modern restaurant, with marble-topped tables and, behind the bar, lucky cat Bearbrick figurines and cans of Café du Monde, they serve the food they eat at home, inspired by recipes from their mothers and aunts. (“Everybody contributed,” Mr. Ly said.) Their approach is respectful of tradition but open-minded, allowing for the likes of unorthodox, yielding short rib in the classically limpid, marrow-deep pho.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/07/19/dining/19HUNGRY-MADAME-slide-U6ST/19HUNGRY-MADAME-slide-U6ST-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-07-13T00:00:00">July 13, 2017</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/13/dining/vietnamese-restaurant-nyc-hanoi-house-madame-vo-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>

<li id="story-id-1248069044105-9">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/11/dining/little-tong-noodle-shop-review-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Little Tong Noodle Shop
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The favorite noodle in the Yunnan Province of southwestern China is a long, round, spaghetti-like rice noodle called mixian. It is the specialty at Little Tong Noodle Shop, a small, new, inexpensive restaurant in the East Village.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044104">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
King Tut Pie
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Middle Eastern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Bay Ridge</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Inside this former bodega just off Fifth Avenue’s strip of halal grocers and Middle Eastern storefronts, Moamen Guirguis and his brother-in-law, Kamel Botros, specialize in feteer meshaltet, whose origins are said to date back to the pharaohs.
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044103">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">

<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/03/dining/abcv-review-vegetables-restaurant-jean-georges-vongerichten.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
ABCV
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Vegan, Vegetarian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Flatiron</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The V in ABCV stands for vegetables, or vegetarian, which the restaurant is. Jean-Georges Vongerichten and his chef de cuisine, Neal Harden, don’t belong to the dour new school of vegetable cookery that tries to do without spices, chiles and citrus. When a vegetable needs a squeeze of lime, squeeze they will.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
