<li id="story-id-1248069044102">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/27/dining/empellon-review-mexican-midtown.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Empellón
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Mexican</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Empellón is the flashiest, fanciest and newest of Alex Stupak’s restaurants, and the one that provides the fullest expression of his dreamscape vision of Mexican food. He doesn’t reproduce or translate the cuisine; he builds a fantasy version of it, coupling deep technical skills with imagination to create a slightly unreal version of reality, the way the best animated movies do.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044101">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/22/dining/queens-night-market-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Queens Night Market
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Small Plates</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Corona</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Of all the city’s open-air food bazaars, none is more surprising, thrilling and inspiring than the Queens Night Market. The bounty seems endless, from vendors representing dozens of countries, a testament to the cultural riches of Queens and the vision of the market‘s founder, John Wang.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Don Peppe
</h2>

<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Italian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">South Ozone Park</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The only menu is the one painted in white on a black patch of the back wall. But regulars don’t need to look before placing an order for baked clams, pasta by the pound, veal or chicken, and shrimp Luciano, one of several dishes served nowhere else in the city.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells

<li id="story-id-1248069044099">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/15/dining/tama-review-filipino-restaurant-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Tama
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Philippine</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Bedford-Stuyvesant</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this ostensible takeout joint, carefully composed Filipino dishes are presented in biodegradable, compostable bowls. The chef, Aniceto Reña, Jr. (known as J.R.), who was born in the Philippines and came to the U.S. as a child, works with memories of flavor and techniques honed in high-end kitchens.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069044098">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/08/dining/bep-ga-review-vietnamese-restaurant-chinatown.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Bep Ga
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Vietnamese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chinatown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This ballerina-pink storefront in Chinatown is a follow-up to Bep, a onetime pop-up that serves Vietnamese classics out of a coffee shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, five nights a week. Here the focus is chicken, poached in a hot bath of ginger, then slipped in the steamer.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069044097">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/06/dining/king-restaurant-review-soho.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
King
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French, Italian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">SoHo</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
King’s two chefs, Jess Shadbolt and Clare de Boer, are so determined not to fall into a rut that they cook a different slate of dishes each night. The changes tend to be evolutionary, drawing from a deep repertory of ideas that borrow liberally from the home cooking of Italy and France.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/06/07/dining/07REST-KING-slide-EDRK/07REST-KING-slide-EDRK-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-06-06T00:00:00">June 6, 2017</time>

<li id="story-id-1248069044096">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/02/dining/western-yunnan-crossing-bridge-noodle-chinese-soup-restaurant-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Western Yunnan Crossing Bridge Noodle
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Of the five broths on offer, ignore the one infiltrated by kimchi, which has heat but little tang, and another with a tomato base that can’t help but invoke, for a Western diner, an attenuated version of Campbell’s tomato soup. Greatness lies elsewhere, in the so-called Original, which is cloudy with fat, from stock made with a whole chicken, and tastes clean and rich at once.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/06/07/dining/07HUNGRY-YUNNAN-slide-XC0L/07HUNGRY-YUNNAN-slide-XC0L-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">

<li id="story-id-1248069044095-10">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/30/dining/tim-ho-wan-review-pinch-chinese-restaurant-dim-sum-dumpling.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Pinch Chinese
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">SoHo</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Sean Tang, who owns Pinch with his cousin, Tony Li, has said that he wants the restaurant to be “region agnostic.” Occasionally this results in stuff that you might cook at home with a recipe from an American magazine. In general, though, the conceit works. The dumplings in particular are very much worthwhile.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044094">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/30/dining/tim-ho-wan-review-pinch-chinese-restaurant-dim-sum-dumpling.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Tim Ho Wan
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese, Dim Sum</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This is the first New York location of a global chain started by a dim sum chef who left a job at the Four Seasons hotel in Hong Kong to get back to basics. The idea is to retain some of the techniques and refinements of high-end dim sum while bringing prices down to sea level.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/05/31/dining/31REST-TIM-HO-WAN-slide-U5TU/31REST-TIM-HO-WAN-slide-U5TU-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044093">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/26/dining/awang-kitchen-review-indonesian-restaurant.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Awang Kitchen
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Indonesian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The menu at this Indonesian restaurant is long and rambling, but the waiters are patient guides. The owner and chef, Siliwanga, known as Awang, grew up in Jakarta on the island of Java, and his specialties include calamari gilded by salted duck egg yolks; catfish fried and smacked with the back of a spoon; and nasi tim ayam jamur, chicken, mushrooms and rice steamed in layers in a bowl and inverted on a plate like a pineapple upside-down cake.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/05/31/dining/31HUNGRY-AWANG-slide-PTUT/31HUNGRY-AWANG-slide-PTUT-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-05-26T00:00:00">May 26, 2017</time>

<li>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Hi-Collar
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
By day, Hi-Collar is a bustling and bright kissaten (Japanese coffeehouse); by night, it’s a moody sake bar where your drink might be poured by a young man with an imperious rockabilly pompadour.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
LIGAYA MISHAN

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Pig Bleecker
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenwich Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this city cousin to Brooklyn’s Pig Beach, the emphasis is on smoke. There are nods to barbecue, but the menu also rounds up unfancy American dishes usually seen at taverns and bars and shacks on the state road just outside town.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells

<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/11/dining/caffe-lanka-review-sri-lankan-restaurant.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Caffé Lanka
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Sri Lankan</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Caffé Lanka — part Sri Lankan restaurant and grocery, part pizzeria, with a sideline in quesadillas, falafel and panini — opened in March by the Castle Hill Avenue subway stop in Parkchester, the Bronx. Sri Lankan food is still a rare sighting in the city outside an immigrant enclave on Staten Island.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

Atoboy
</h2>

<li id="story-id-1248069044087">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/04/dining/la-esquina-del-camaron-mexicano-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
La Esquina del Camarón Mexicano
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Jackson Heights</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At the back of a bodega two aisles wide, Pedro Rodriguez stands as studious as an apothecary, quietly filling plastic cups with shrimp, purplish nubs of octopus and a red liquid that looks lit from within. Topped by a small riot of cilantro and crescents of avocado, it is half cocktail, half remedy — a conjuring of Veracruz, Mexico. It’s best when you work all the flavors and textures into one spoonful: bright, creamy, meaty, salty-sweet.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/05/10/dining/10HUNGRY-LA-ESQUINA-slide-BSJA/10HUNGRY-LA-ESQUINA-slide-BSJA-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-05-04T00:00:00">May 4, 2017</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">

<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/04/dining/la-esquina-del-camaron-mexicano-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>

<li id="story-id-1248069044086">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/02/dining/loring-place-review-greenwich-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Loring Place
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenwich Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Dan Kluger, who made his name at ABC Kitchen, cooks a menu that follows the ABC template closely, from salads and saladlike constructions to the cheeseburger and whole-wheat pizzas. One new item stands out: the grandma-style pan pizza, a less doughy Sicilian.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Together
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian</li>

<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The city’s lone Burmese restaurant brings the rings and chain links of the Burmese alphabet to a Brooklyn street otherwise inscribed in English, Russian and Mandarin. The owner opened the restaurant after a brief run selling Burmese food in a bodega on Avenue U.

<li id="story-id-1002207995231">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Union Square Cafe
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>

<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Italian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Gramercy Park</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Other restaurants have customers; Union Square Cafe has fans, and knows it. Almost everything about the new location on Park Avenue caters to their memories of the original. But the restaurant has a combination of energy and well-honed familiarity that’s rare in Manhattan.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069044084">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/20/dining/la-roja-de-todos-review-chilean-food-corona-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
La Roja de Todos
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Latin American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Corona</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The restaurant’s name is in homage to the Chilean national soccer team, which is close to the heart of José Luis Norambuena, the owner, a native of Valparaíso, Chile. Vania Isler, his daughter, patiently steers those unfamiliar with her native cuisine toward dishes “you can find only here” — like pastel de choclo, a casserole topped with a charred crust of corn and basil, on which she suggests sprinkling sugar.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044081">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/13/dining/wafas-express-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Wafa’s Express
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Middle Eastern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The menu at this mostly takeout spot could belong to any of the city’s frill-free Middle Eastern restaurants. But everything here is a little bit more — brighter, earthier, smokier, creamier. The difference is like a washed-out photograph that has been suddenly restored, gaining colors and textures you did not know were there.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044080">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/11/dining/torishin-review-japanese-yakitori.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Torishin
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Clinton</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Over charcoal tended by the attentive chefs at Torishin, each part of the chicken has a different form of pleasure to offer: chew or crunch, subtlety or visceral impact. While some yakitori places favor sweet sauces and heavy blackening, the house style is sensitive to timing, averse to charring, and careful with seasoning.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044079">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/06/dining/mama-lee-review-taiwanese-food-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Mama Lee
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese, Taiwanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Bayside</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Mei Lee, the eponymous owner of this small, plain-spoken Taiwanese restaurant, is a no-nonsense figure in apron and bandanna, comfortingly bossy. With the help of her uncle in the kitchen, she makes homey, frankly appealing dishes like three-cup chicken, lion’s head meatballs and lu rou fan (ground pork braised in soy sauce and Shaoxing wine and poured over rice). Hours are erratic — Ms. Lee likes her freedom — so call ahead.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<li id="story-id-1002207983093">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/04/dining/babbo-review-pete-wells.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Babbo
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Italian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenwich Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Mario Batali and his business partner, Joe Bastianich, own about two dozen restaurants in the United States and Asia. Babbo is the empire’s spiritual home, where the original formula of adventure and pleasure and curious-minded indulgence is still intact, and where you can still try recipes that sprang from Mr. Batali’s head when he was just a minor celebrity.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

<li id="story-id-1248069044078">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/30/dining/neerob-review-packsun-halal-chicken-bangladesh-food.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Neerob at Packsun Halal Chicken
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Bangladeshi</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Parkchester</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Neerob, a Bangladeshi restaurant thought by many to be the city’s best, closed last year and re-opened a few blocks away inside a halal fried chicken joint. There the fried chicken is now overshadowed by a steam table of Bangladeshi dishes charged with mustard oil and green chiles, and beautiful sweets like rounds of rice-powder dough carved by hand with a wooden needle.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044077">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/28/dining/augustine-review-french-food-nyc-keith-mcnally.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Augustine
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Financial District</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Augustine has the prettiest, giddiest interior Keith McNally has ever done. The Parisian flashback mood is so successful that it doesn’t matter whether the food resembles anything you might eat in Paris itself.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

<li id="story-id-1248069044076">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/21/dining/sugarfish-by-sushi-nozawa-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Sugarfish by Sushi Nozawa
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-word-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="1">

<span class="visually-hidden"></span>

Fair
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese, Sushi</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Flatiron</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Serious sushi can be expensive, and diners who are ready to move up from entry-level quality but don’t have a lot of money to spend can have a hard time figuring out where to go. Sugarfish, which comes to town with a Los Angeles pedigree, would like to be the answer. It’s not.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044075-12">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/14/dining/franklin-barbecue-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Franklin Barbecue
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Barbecue</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Austin, Tex.</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
When you finally reach the front of the line at Franklin Barbecue, you're asked how much brisket you want. Several considerations come into play, of course, like the elasticity of your stomach and your taste for pork, smoked sausage and turkey. But brisket is the foundation on which Franklin Barbecue was built, brisket as it is seasoned and barbecued by the owner and chief pitmaster, Aaron Franklin.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/03/15/dining/15REST-FRANKLIN-slide-HMM7/15REST-FRANKLIN-slide-HMM7-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-03-14T00:00:00">March 14, 2017</time>

<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/14/dining/franklin-barbecue-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>

<li id="story-id-1248069044074">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/09/dining/butterfunk-kitchen-review-soul-food-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Butterfunk Kitchen
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Southern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Windsor Terrace</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Chris Scott, the chef, built his menu on memories of his Nana’s cooking, church picnics and neighborhood potlucks. Deviled eggs, deep-fried corn on the cob, scrapple and fried chicken with a gilding of lemonade honor both his Pennsylvania Dutch and Virginia roots. On Wednesday nights, his wife, Eugenie Woo, brings her heritage to the table with chicken wings in a fever of Korean gochujang, fermented chile paste. Mr. Scott’s mother, who always carried hot sauce in her purse, would approve.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/03/15/dining/butterfunk-kitchen-TIPS/Hungry-butterfunkss-slide-TIPS-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-03-09T00:00:00">March 9, 2017</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/09/dining/butterfunk-kitchen-review-soul-food-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044073">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/02/dining/little-egypt-review-ridgewood-queens-restaurant.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Little Egypt
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Middle Eastern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Ridgewood</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Nashaat Youssef, the chef, grew up in Alexandria, Egypt’s largest seaport, and spent a decade cooking at a restaurant steps from the docks; here he takes special pride in his fish, including a whole branzino crusted with cracked wheat and blackened over charcoal. His wife, Yvette, helps in the kitchen, and his sons, Mark and Wadie, pitch in when not at school. Up front, a cluster of tables are set with plastic black damask placemats and electric candles; in the back, grocery shelves can be read like a library, a scholarship of fava beans and black molasses.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/03/08/dining/08HUNGRY-LITTLE-EGYPT-slide-3RGT/08HUNGRY-LITTLE-EGYPT-slide-3RGT-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-03-02T00:00:00">March 2, 2017</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/02/dining/little-egypt-review-ridgewood-queens-restaurant.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044072">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/23/dining/bhutanese-food-weekender-billiard-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Weekender Billiard
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Woodside</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
In a corner of this Bhutanese snooker club, portraits of the Dalai Lama and the king and queen of Bhutan tilt over a huddle of dining tables. Under their gaze, the waiter brings plates of ema datse, the Bhutanese daily meal of chiles and cheese; earthy red rice from high elevations in the Paro Valley; and black tea churned forever with salt and a pat of butter. Tourists to Bhutan must commit to spend $200 to $250 a day in the country; here in Queens, snooker tables go for $13 an hour.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/03/01/dining/01HUNGRY-WEEKENDER-slide-1IXV/01HUNGRY-WEEKENDER-slide-1IXV-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-02-23T00:00:00">Feb. 23, 2017</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/23/dining/bhutanese-food-weekender-billiard-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044071">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/21/dining/sahib-review-indian-restaurant-nyc.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Sahib
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Indian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Kips Bay</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Sahib darts around India. The menu pays a little bit of attention to several regions and ignores others entirely. This makes it hard to get a firm sense of any one regional style, but easy to enjoy a handful of dishes you may have never seen before.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069044070">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/16/dining/cafe-lily-review-bensonhurst-korean-uzbek.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Cafe Lily
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian, Korean, Russian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Bensonhurst</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Lilia Tyan, the chef, grew up in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, a descendant of Korean settlers in far eastern Russia who were relocated under Stalin’s orders to the steppes of central Asia. Her menu, in Russian and in English, includes traditional Uzbek dishes; the surprises come from the Korean larder. Most nights find her family gathered for dinner, with her daughters-in-law getting up from their meals to take customers’ orders, sometimes with their small children tugging at their sleeves.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044069">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/14/dining/chinese-tuxedo-restaurant-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Chinese Tuxedo
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chinatown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Situated in the stripped-down bones of the first Chinese theater in New York, Chinese Tuxedo has a vintage air and a gleam of drama. The menu is described as fusion, but it is the smart kind of fusion and often has discernible Chinese antecedents.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044068">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/09/dining/dek-sen-review-thai-food-elmhurst-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Dek Sen
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Thai</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Elmhurst</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
In this shallow storefront with red gingham tablecloths and rainbow twinkle lights, Wirot Sirimatrasit cooks alongside his mother, Ramphai Rinnasak, a native of Phetchabun in the north of Thailand. They focus on the kind of unshowy, full-flavored dishes that are the running stitch of a Thai childhood. This is food as balm for the homesick, speaking directly to the Thai immigrants who live in the neighborhood — although all are welcome.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/02/15/dining/15HUNGRY-DEKSEN-slide-KSNF/15HUNGRY-DEKSEN-slide-KSNF-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-02-09T00:00:00">Feb. 9, 2017</time>

<li id="story-id-1248069044067">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/07/dining/white-gold-butchers-review-april-bloomfield-restaurant.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
White Gold Butchers
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Upper West Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
In this restaurant inside a butcher shop, the menu gets right to the point, no small talk. The main courses fall under the heading Plates. There are usually four of them, grilled very simply, for dinner. For lunch the focus is on savory pastries, like pasties and stubby little sausage rolls.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/02/08/dining/08REST-WHITEGOLD-slide-LXVD/08REST-WHITEGOLD-slide-LXVD-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-02-07T00:00:00">Feb. 7, 2017</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/07/dining/white-gold-butchers-review-april-bloomfield-restaurant.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

<li>
<a class="reserve-table" href="https://resy.com/cities/ny/white-gold-butchers?utm_source=nyt&amp;utm_medium=restoprofile&amp;utm_campaign=affiliates&amp;aff_id=c1fe784" target="_blank" title="Reserve a Table">Reserve a Table</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044066">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/02/dining/the-gumbo-bros-review-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Gumbo Bros
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Southern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Boerum Hill</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The chef Adam Lathan grew up on the Gulf Coast of Alabama, in Creole country; his business partner, Clay Boulware, comes from Cajun central Louisiana. Former college roommates, they reunited in New York a few years ago to redress the city’s scarcity of gumbo. Here, in a space full of New Orleans-inspired touches, Mr. Lathan serves a Cajun gumbo that speaks in smoke, and a Creole style that relies on the sweetness of shrimp and blue crabs.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/02/08/dining/08HUNGRY-GUMBO-BROS-slide-YSLO/08HUNGRY-GUMBO-BROS-slide-YSLO-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-02-02T00:00:00">Feb. 2, 2017</time>

<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/02/dining/the-gumbo-bros-review-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044065-13">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/31/dining/chumleys-review-bar-west-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Chumley’s
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">West Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At the address of a famous former speakeasy is a restaurant that has nothing in common with the original except a name, a door, an archway and framed photographs of, and jackets of books by, writers who used to drink there. The old regulars would have taken one look at the new menu and called for another shot, but the cooking is exciting; some of it even resembles bar food.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044064">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/26/dining/fob-review-filipino-restaurant-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
F.O.B.
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Philippine</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Carroll Gardens</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The chef, Armando Litiatco, was born in the Philippines and grew up in Daly City, Calif., which has the country’s highest concentration of people of Filipino descent. Here he serves delicate versions of classic Filipino dishes, in a gracious dining room with roomy chairs and light bulbs that rest like cockatoos in wrought-iron bird-cage lanterns. Food comes on grandmotherly, mismatched china; family members beam from framed photos.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044063">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/24/dining/fowler-and-wells-restaurant-review-beekman-hotel.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Fowler &amp; Wells
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Financial District</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Tom Colicchio, the chef and owner, tries to bring some Gilded Age exuberance to this restaurant in a restored 1883 building. Many of the components, including the cocktails, wine list and desserts, are excellent. But in the menu and the décor, the central vision is fuzzy, and the restaurant is somehow less than the sum of its parts.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<div class="story-body">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Lhasa Fast Food
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Tibetan</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Jackson Heights</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The cooking at Lhasa Fast Food — cauldrons of dusky broths, heavy with hand-torn scraps of dough and humming with Sichuan peppercorns; momos looking ready to burst their pleats — would be worth seeking out even if it were served in a sleek food hall in Midtown Manhattan.
</p>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Ichiran, a Japanese ramen chain, makes one kind of soup, the opaque ivory pork broth called tonkotsu. But it presents a boggling number of choices, starting with whether to sit at a table or in one of the “flavor concentration booths.”

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Very Fresh Noodles
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chelsea</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
“Biang biang” is both the name of the noodles stretched to order at this cramped corner stall in Chelsea Market — straps of dough as wide as a belt, drawn out to the wingspan of their maker — and the sound of them snapping against the counter.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Flora Bar
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Japanese, Spanish</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Upper East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Flora Bar, inside the Met Breuer, is less a restaurant than a wine bar, with small, tidily formal plates and a drinks list as exhaustive as any artist’s career retrospective.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">

<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069044058">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/05/dining/karu-cafe-review-woodside-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Karu Café
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Latin American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Woodside</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
In this unassuming storefront, two chefs cook side by side, one from Paraguay, the other from Venezuela: harmony between otherwise quarreling nations. Venezuelan arepas, airy corn cakes barely a finger’s width thick, may share the table with Paraguayan chipas, dense, bulging curls of cassava flour and cornmeal fattened by cheese, eggs, milk and butter and tasting like gougères after a gravitational collapse. Karu means “to eat” in Guaraní, the indigenous language written into Paraguay’s Constitution as equal to Spanish, defying the legacy of the conquistadors.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/01/11/dining/11HUNGRY-KARU-slide-8Y6W/11HUNGRY-KARU-slide-8Y6W-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2017-01-05T00:00:00">Jan. 5, 2017</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/05/dining/karu-cafe-review-woodside-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>
</li>
<li id="story-id-1248069044056">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/27/dining/the-odeon-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Odeon
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">TriBeCa</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The kitchen retrenched years ago to a comfortably broken-in lineup of French and American standards. Cooking like this is sometimes called comfort food, but a better word for the menu and everything else about the Odeon is restorative.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

<li id="story-id-1248069044055">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/20/dining/cut-by-wolfgang-puck-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Cut by Wolfgang Puck
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Steak Houses</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Financial District</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Wolfgang Puck’s hotel steakhouse, his first venture in Manhattan, felt dated as soon as it opened. The steaks are excellent; other dishes are appealing, if a little unfocused, and the interior design appears to have been lost in the mail for a decade or so.
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/12/21/dining/21REST-CUT-slide-Y25P/21REST-CUT-slide-Y25P-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044054-14">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/15/dining/pata-cafe-review-thai-food-elmhurst-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Pata Cafe
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Thai</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Elmhurst</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this offshoot of the Thai bar Pata Paplean, a tree climbs from the floor through the ceiling. It’s as if you’d popped through a trap door into a secret clubhouse. Sunisa Nitmai, a native of Isan, Thailand’s northeast, cooks as she would at home: plain-spoken Thai dishes, none over $10, that taste of gestures timeworn but never taken for granted, and of honest pleasure in what a handful of ingredients can do.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/12/21/dining/21HUNGRY-PATA-CAFE-slide-C4YD/21HUNGRY-PATA-CAFE-slide-C4YD-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069043386">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/06/dining/aska-review-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Aska
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Scandinavian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Over the past several years, few chefs have grown into their ambitions as dramatically and successfully as Aska’s, Fredrik Berselius. Aska, beneath the ribs of the Williamsburg Bridge in July, is his third restaurant; with each fresh incarnation, his modern Scandinavian, nature-boy cooking has taken a leap forward.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<div class="wide-thumb">

<li id="story-id-1248069044053">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/01/dining/mala-project-review-sichuan-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
MaLa Project
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
All the hidden animal corners that other civilizations treasure but tend to make ours nervous appear at this modern Chinese restaurant, part of an inventory of some sixty-odd potential ingredients for Sichuan dry pot. Four levels of “spiciness” are on offer; even a veteran fire-eater needn’t go past three.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044052">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/29/dining/bad-saint-dc-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Bad Saint
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Philippine</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Washington D.C.</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Bad Saint was built to make the best of its scarce square footage, not to handle the pressure of being one of Washington’s most sought-after restaurants. Now it has to do both, because the food prepared under columns of wok smoke is richly compelling no matter how many prior run-ins you’ve had with Filipino food.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044051">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/25/dining/mumbai-xpress-review-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Mumbai Xpress
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Indian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Floral Park</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Other places in town serve chaat, a vast genre of Indian snacks fueled by salt and tang, but perhaps none with the same range and single-minded devotion as Mumbai Xpress. The menu's vivid offerings testify to the wisdom of a culture that respects snacks, makes them by hand and gives them nuance, layers and colliding flavors.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/11/30/dining/30HUNGRY-MUMBAI-slide-PVFG/30HUNGRY-MUMBAI-slide-PVFG-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-11-25T00:00:00">Nov. 25, 2016</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/25/dining/mumbai-xpress-review-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>

</footer>

<li id="story-id-1248069044049">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/23/dining/alimentos-saludables-review-brooklyn-tamales.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Alimentos Saludables
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Sunset Park</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This Mexican diner serves some of the best tamales in town, slapped on a paper plate and trussed in corn husks still damp with steam. Unshucked, they seem almost to breathe. The dough is soft and marbled with sauce, so that a little finds its way into every bite. Concepción Gonzalez, the chef, who started out selling tamales in front of a nearby church, is an efficient, motherly presence. A statue of baby Jesus in gold robes gazes pacifically from a glass case; Héctor Acosta might be singing merengue on the jukebox. The menu lists five varieties of tamales, most of which will be sold out by dinnertime, so come early.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/11/23/dining/23HUNGRY-ALIMENTOS-slide-5T22/23HUNGRY-ALIMENTOS-slide-5T22-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-11-23T00:00:00">Nov. 23, 2016</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/23/dining/alimentos-saludables-review-brooklyn-tamales.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>

<li id="story-id-1248069044050">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Fish Cheeks
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Thai</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">NoHo</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Specializing in a small number of seafood dishes from around Thailand, Fish Cheeks is not a groundbreaking experiment; it simply cooks the way more Thai kitchens should.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
