<li id="story-id-1248069044047">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/16/dining/thursday-kitchen-review-korean-restaurant-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Thursday Kitchen
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian, Korean</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Thursday Kitchen has more interesting cooking than you might expect from a restaurant that serves illuminated cocktails in plastic bags, like debauched Capri Suns. Kyungmin Kay Hyun, the chef, a native of South Korea, ferments her own ponzu for 30 days to accompany her exemplary pajeon (scallion pancake); pairs charred octopus with a chardonnay gelée and a Korean barbecue-like tincture of soy, scallions and Asian pear; and tempers crispy pork belly with white kimchi, so called because it’s made without chile, privileging funk over heat.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/11/16/dining/16HUNGRY-THURSDAY-KITCHEN-slide-TKRQ/16HUNGRY-THURSDAY-KITCHEN-slide-TKRQ-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-11-16T00:00:00">Nov. 16, 2016</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/16/dining/thursday-kitchen-review-korean-restaurant-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044048">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/16/dining/tsurutontan-udon-noodle-brasserie-restaurant-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
TsuruTonTan Udon Noodle Brasserie
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Union Square</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
It’s now easier to find a ramen shop in Manhattan than a mailbox, but udon specialists are rare. TsuruTonTan may be the only one that mixes, kneads, rolls and cuts the dough for these long, pale wheat noodles in its own kitchen.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044046">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/09/dining/paowalla-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Paowalla
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Indian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">SoHo</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Reaching into his back catalog, the chef Floyd Cardoz is serving some dishes and even a couple of cocktails, like the mind-clearing cucumber-gin highball called the Kachumber Cooler, that are flashbacks to the much-missed Tabla and Bread Bar.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044045-15">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/09/dining/violets-bake-shoppe-review-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Violet’s Bake Shoppe
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Vietnamese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Forest Hills</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this Chinese bakery with a sideline in Vietnamese banh mi, the ratios — of bread to charcuterie (almost all made in-house) to pickles to condiments — are golden. The bread is a cloud in crisp armor, with a crust that snaps like kindling, and then the sandwich is all creaminess, salt and heat, deeply basal flavors and brisk, bright ones, every note seemingly struck at once.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/11/09/dining/09HUNGRY-VIOLETS-slide-5K9L/09HUNGRY-VIOLETS-slide-5K9L-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-11-09T00:00:00">Nov. 9, 2016</time>

<li id="story-id-1248069044043">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/02/dining/divine-flavored-nigerian-food-truck-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Divine Flavored Nigerian Food Truck
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">African</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown East</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Godshelter Oluwalogbon, the chef behind this Nigerian food truck with bright green hubcaps and a beach scene on its flank, was born in Ghana, his mother’s homeland, and raised in Nigeria, his father’s. On weekdays, he parks in front of the Nigerian Consulate, offering the likes of gizdodo, chicken gizzards folded with caramelized plantains; asun, dark, smoky goat meat sifted with pulverized Scotch bonnets; and ayamase, a chunky stew loaded with beef, tripe and flagrantly rubbery curls of cow skin.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/11/02/dining/02HUNGRY-DEVINE-FLAVORED-slide-C41S/02HUNGRY-DEVINE-FLAVORED-slide-C41S-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Le Coucou
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>

<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French</li>

<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Daniel Rose’s first restaurant in New York, the cooking is informed by old-school traditions, focuses on animal parts, and revolves around glossy, spoon-coating, cream- and butter-reinforced sauces.

Pete Wells

<li id="story-id-1248069044042">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/26/dining/sushi-on-jones-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Sushi on Jones
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese, Sushi</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">NoHo</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This tiny, no-frills open-air sushi bar is one of five kiosks in the Bowery Market food court, on a lot once home to an auto-repair shop. Guests are given 30 minutes to dine; the clock starts at reservation time. This might seem ruthless, but the price is kind: $50 for 12 pieces of beautifully fresh fish. The menu reads like a classic-rock playlist — hamachi, salmon, tuna — but there are surprises, like scallop with smoky black salt and uni draped over seared wagyushu beef.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/10/26/dining/23HUNGRY-GREAT-JONES-SUSH-slide-5L7H/23HUNGRY-GREAT-JONES-SUSH-slide-5L7H-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-10-26T00:00:00">Oct. 26, 2016</time>

<li id="story-id-1248069043571">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/26/dining/beatrice-inn-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Beatrice Inn
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">West Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
It’s called a chophouse, but the Beatrice Inn is not a place for cautious eaters seeking refuge from the unknown. The menu, almost entirely devoted to meat, is an opportunity to take chances and eat with abandon.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069044039">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/19/dining/great-northern-food-hall-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Great Northern Food Hall
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Scandinavian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown East</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
There’s something utopian about the notion that even a hasty, inconsequential meal, gobbled on a train or at a desk, can be — should be — fresh and good. That’s the mission of this impeccably polished food hall, opened in Grand Central Terminal by the Danish restaurateur Claus Meyer, a founder of Noma, in Copenhagen, and a prime mover in defining New Nordic cuisine.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

Karasu
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Fort Greene</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Karasu is a speakeasy behind the back wall of a corner tavern. The first surprising thing about the food is that there is any. The second is that it’s so polished and considered.

<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells

<li id="story-id-1248069044038">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/12/dining/pondicheri-restaurant-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Pondicheri
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Indian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">NoMad</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
There isn’t another restaurant in the city quite like Pondicheri, where from breakast through dinner the flavors of India are imported into American daily life.

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">

<li id="story-id-1248069044037">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/12/dining/chinese-club-review-williamsburg.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Chinese Club
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese, Indian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The Chinese Club looks like a straightforwardly (if self-consciously kitschy) Chinese restaurant. But the food is as Chinese as General Tso’s chicken — diaspora cuisine, filtered through another nation’s consciousness, in this case India’s.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044035-16">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/05/dining/dim-sum-joy-luck-palace-chinatown.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Joy Luck Palace
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese, Dim Sum</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chinatown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Much of the food — classics like stuffed bitter melon alongside faddishly cute pig-shaped custard buns — is good, if not transcendent, at this dim sum hall in Manhattan’s Chinatown. Expect a long wait and mayhem.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</h2>

<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenpoint</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At its best, Sauvage seems to be on to something exciting, a combination of European kitchen discipline and a gut instinct for meeting the appetite head on.

By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069044033">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/28/dining/korean-bbq-tong-sam-gyup-goo-yi-flushing-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Tong Sam Gyup Goo Yi
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Korean</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Flushing</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this barbecue restaurant, the gleaming black grill plate on each table mimics the lid of a traditional Korean cauldron, allowing the pork belly’s drippings to run down into the wreath of bean sprouts, kimchi and garlic cloves snapping on the hot iron below.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">

<li id="story-id-1248069044030">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/21/dining/2nd-city-west-village-swell-dive-bedford-stuyvesant.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
2nd City
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Philippine</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">West Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this Filipino-leaning taqueria, the chef Jordan Andino turns lumpia wrappers into chips, for dunking in suka; anoints tacos with sinigang, a tangy tamarind soup; and otherwise makes what he calls “AmAsian,” or American-Asian, food — more general than specific.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044032">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/21/dining/gunter-seeger-ny-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Günter Seeger NY
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">West Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Günter Seeger, who made his name in Atlanta in the 1990s and 2000s, is a deeply expressive chef — expressive of the season and of his own focused, disciplined style. When you’re surprised by his cooking, it’s because the voice of the ingredients is coming through more clearly than you’re used to.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/09/21/dining/21REST-GUNTERSEEGER-slide-UNOZ/21REST-GUNTERSEEGER-slide-UNOZ-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044028">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/14/dining/nepalese-food-woodside-cafe-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Woodside Cafe
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Woodside</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Woodside Cafe was once a mostly Italian, partly Nepalese restaurant, opened by a native of Kathmandu who spent 14 years cooking Italian food on the Upper East Side. Now the only trace of the Mediterranean is a pink sauce of tomatoes and heavy cream ladled over momos, Himalayan dumplings.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/09/14/dining/14HUNGRY-WOODSIDE-slide-9QZY/14HUNGRY-WOODSIDE-slide-9QZY-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-09-14T00:00:00">Sept. 14, 2016</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/14/dining/nepalese-food-woodside-cafe-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>

<li id="story-id-1248069044026">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/07/dining/tsion-cafe-harlem.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Tsion Cafe
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Ethiopian, Middle Eastern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Harlem</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Beejhy Barhany, the chef, was born in northern Ethiopia into a community of Beta Israel, as Ethiopian Jews are known. Her menu can read like a biography: eggs scrambled with lox over injera, the sour, springy Ethiopian flatbread perforated like coral; challah French toast spiked with awaze, a meld of earthy-hot berbere and tej, Ethiopian honey wine.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/09/07/dining/07HUNGRY-TSION-CAFE-slide-B10A/07HUNGRY-TSION-CAFE-slide-B10A-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-09-07T00:00:00">Sept. 7, 2016</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/07/dining/tsion-cafe-harlem.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>

<li id="story-id-1248069044027">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/07/dining/cassia-santa-monica-restaurant-review-pete-wells.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Cassia
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian, Vietnamese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Santa Monica, Calif.</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
One of the most appealing things about Cassia is its pointed lack of interest in being confrontational. The restaurant goes out of its way to be accommodating, without doing too much violence to the various Asian cuisines (Vietnamese in particular) that inspire much of the menu.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/09/07/dining/07REST-CASSIA-slide-0Z5M/07REST-CASSIA-slide-0Z5M-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">

<li id="story-id-1248069044024-17">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/31/dining/dizengoff-gyro96-nyc.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Dizengoff
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Middle Eastern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chelsea</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
An outpost of an acclaimed Philadelphia hummus counter, Dizengoff offers pita straight out of the oven, swollen and chewy at the edges with pocks of scorch, and hummus made every hour and a half.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/08/31/dining/31-HUNGRY-DIZENGOFF-slide-IA7N/31-HUNGRY-DIZENGOFF-slide-IA7N-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-08-31T00:00:00">Aug. 31, 2016</time>

<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/31/dining/dizengoff-gyro96-nyc.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>

<li id="story-id-1248069044025">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/31/dining/dizengoff-gyro96-nyc.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Gyro96
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Middle Eastern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Harlem</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this 85-square-foot falafel shop steps from the 96th Street subway station, Waled Haredy, a native of Egypt, offers gyro at street-cart prices and makes falafel to order from his mother’s recipe, which belonged to her mother and her grandmother before her.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044023">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/24/dining/bolivian-llama-party-nyc.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Bolivian Llama Party
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Latin American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This stand run by three brothers with roots in Cochabamba, Bolivia, specializes in salteñas, which must not be mistaken for empanadas. The dough is sweet and thick, as chewy as an underbaked cookie, and it is filled with a soupy stew, cooked for days and lush with broken-down cow’s foot, that threatens to gush at first bite.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044022">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Bohemian Spirit
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Eastern European</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Yorkville</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this Czech restaurant on the ground floor of the 120-year-old Bohemian National Hall, the mission is nostalgic nourishment -- this means beer-hall food served by no-nonsense waitresses in a lofty room.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

Gramercy Tavern

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

<li id="story-id-1248069044021">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/10/dining/olmsted-restaurant-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Olmsted
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Prospect Heights</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Not much about the dining room sets Olmsted apart from any number of other new places to eat. But the quail coop and crayfish tub in the backyard, and the thoughtful, inventive food coming out of the tiny kitchen, tell you that hidden inside this simple and affordable neighborhood restaurant is another, more unusual one waiting to get out.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/08/10/dining/10REST-OLMSTEAD-slide-1D0Z/10REST-OLMSTEAD-slide-1D0Z-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044020">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/03/dining/agern-restaurant-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Agern
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Scandinavian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown East</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Agern feels like a quiet harbor away from the eddies and currents of Grand Central Terminal. In the modern Scandinavian dining room, pale wood, charcoal seat cushions and wall tiles in mossy Grand Central green create a calming mood. Buying food raised around New York, Agern treats the city as another Scandinavian capital: Oslo-on-Hudson.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/08/03/dining/03RESTJP3/03RESTJP3-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-08-03T00:00:00">Aug. 3, 2016</time>

<li id="story-id-1248069044018">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/27/dining/dawas-restaurant-queens-tibetan-food.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Dawa’s
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Tibetan</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Woodside</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Dawa Bhuti, a young immigrant of Tibetan descent, cooks alongside her father, Ngodup Gyaltsen. The front side of the menu, devoted to brunch dishes of almost Californian lightness, is hers; the thrill is the hidden tracks, listed on the back as “ethnic plates” — Mr. Gyaltsen’s contribution from the hometown he had to leave behind.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/07/27/dining/27HUNGRY-DAWA-slide-1BI4/27HUNGRY-DAWA-slide-1BI4-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-07-27T00:00:00">July 27, 2016</time>

<li id="story-id-1248069044019">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/27/dining/pasquale-jones-review-little-italy.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Pasquale Jones
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Italian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Little Italy</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The menu flits from pizza to pasta to the inevitable small plates to a rib-eye for two; most of the food is cooked in wood-burning ovens; and the noteworthy wine list roams beyond Italy and offers bottles that used to be considered too good for a pizza parlor.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Beach Bistro 96
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>

<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">The Rockaways</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Carlos Vallera, who grew up in the Brazilian port town Santos, opened this low-slung sea shack a block from Rockaway Beach after another life as a pro surfer and model. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">

<li id="story-id-1248069044015-18">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/13/dining/burmese-food-new-york.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Burma Noodle Bar
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Southeast Asian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Sunset Park</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this makeshift stand in the Industry City Food Hall, the owner Eugene Saw offers samusas — flatter and daintier than Indian samosas — and three bowls of noodles, each better than the last, no matter what order you eat them in.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069044014">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/13/dining/burmese-food-new-york.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Burmese Bites
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Southeast Asian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Corona</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
For nearly two decades, the only place to find Myo Lin Thway’s palata (also known, more poetically, as hundred-layer bread) was at a once-a-year church fair. But now, at Burmese Bites on Saturdays at the Queens International Night Market, he serves three dishes, at $5 each; they make you wish he cooked every night, year-round.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/07/13/dining/13HUNGRY-BURMESE-BITES-slide-GHC3/13HUNGRY-BURMESE-BITES-slide-GHC3-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-07-13T00:00:00">July 13, 2016</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/13/dining/burmese-food-new-york.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>

<li id="story-id-1248069044016">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/13/dining/mimi-restaurant-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Mimi
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenwich Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
It’s an updated version of the small French restaurant everybody dreams of finding in the Village. The kitchen is small and still figuring things out, but it has a clear vision of French food as a celebration of appetite, an occasion to eat with joy and lust.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Liberated from the ideologies of vegetarianism, Nix is free to pursue the hedonic values of vegetables.

<li id="story-id-1248069044012">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/06/dining/phil-am-kusina-filipino-food-staten-island.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Phil-Am Kusina
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Philippine</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Rosebank</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This Filipino restaurant on the North Shore of Staten Island is run by Manny Imperial, a young chef who started working at age 5 at his parents’ grocery down the street. Portions are generous, prices kind, and the menu mostly reassuring to those unfamiliar with the cuisine. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069044011">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/29/dining/freeks-mill-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Freek’s Mill
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Gowanus</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Freek’s Mill looks not very different from other young, ingredient-minded Brooklyn restaurants. But the wine list is wonderfully eccentric, heavily weighted with chenin blanc and gamay. These wines are flexible, wrapping themselves around whatever you happen to be eating. This is lucky, because so many things on Chad Shaner’s menu are worth trying.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/06/29/dining/29REST-FREEKSMILL-slide-4D4K/29REST-FREEKSMILL-slide-4D4K-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044010">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/29/dining/the-crabby-shack-seafood-restaurant-crown-heights.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Crabby Shack
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Seafood</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Crown Heights</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this airy temple to crab, framed in white and sea blue, there are no whole crabs in buckets, no butcher paper on the tables. But almost everything on the menu is a tribute to the crustacean.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
District Saigon
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Vietnamese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Astoria</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this restaurant run by a Vietnamese-born father and his American-raised son, the depth of the pho is something of a surprise, given other offerings that seem slightly canted to please American palates.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Grünauer Bistro
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Although it opened in early March, it might have been frying Wiener schnitzel and simmering tafelspitz on the corner of First Avenue and 82nd Street for decades.

<li id="story-id-1248069044006">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/15/dining/caridad-china-restaurant-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Caridad China
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese, Latin</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
As at other Chino Latino restaurants in New York City, no cross-pollination of seasonings is allowed, only congenial cohabitation on the table. The Chinese dishes are truer to the Chinese restaurants of 1980s America than to China, which means everything has a slightly caramel edge.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044007-19">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/15/dining/le-coq-rico-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Le Coq Rico
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Flatiron</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
A branch of a Parisian “bistro for beautiful birds” founded by the chef Antoine Westermann, Le Coq Rico is the perfect place to take people who believe they can make a better roast chicken at home.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069044004">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/08/dining/b-and-k-french-cuisine-harlem-hungry-city.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
B &amp; K French Cuisine
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Harlem</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Benjamin Baccari Kebe, the owner and chef of this tiny Harlem storefront, brings classical French technique to a simple, gently priced menu, braising beef for hours just for a sandwich and making fish and chips with a batter so buoyant, it looks like armored air.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/06/08/dining/08HUNGRY-BK-FRENCH-slide-76KR/08HUNGRY-BK-FRENCH-slide-76KR-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069044005">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/08/dining/la-sirena-restaurant-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
La Sirena
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Italian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chelsea</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
La Sirena has two dining rooms connected by a bar with the approximate dimensions of a jet runway. It's so large that somebody is always on the move. That perpetual motion supplies a lot of La Sirena’s energy; the rest comes from the dressy trattoria cooking.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/06/08/dining/08REST-LA-SIRENA-slide-Y0VU/08REST-LA-SIRENA-slide-Y0VU-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Nabaya
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">African</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Melrose</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this West African restaurant only a few dishes are ever available, but they are worth it: by day, stews briny with smoked fish and crawfish powder; by night, large, single-minded plates of meat needled with Scotch bonnets.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069043999">

<div class="story-body">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
King of Falafel &amp; Shawarma
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Middle Eastern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Astoria</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
For 14 years, Fares Zeideia, known as Freddy, plied a street cart on the corner of Broadway and 30th Street in Astoria, Queens, and at his first bricks-and-mortar restaurant, the falafel and shawarma are as great as they ever were, served in a dining room decorated in bright red and green, to keep the atmosphere “not too official.”
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

</h2>

<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chinatown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Taiwan Bear House in Chinatown, biodegradable wooden boxes are packed with rice and topped with crusty pork chop, slabs of pork belly or chicken twice fried in the night-market style.

Angela’s
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Caribbean</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Bedford-Stuyvesant</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At her namesake restaurant, due north of some of the city’s more celebrated Trinidadian roti and doubles shops, Angela Pellew-Whyte presents pan-Caribbean dishes — saltfish and bake, curry goat, a profound oxtail stew — under a wooden chandelier, as what sounds like one eternal song loops from the speakers.
</p>

</h2>

<li id="story-id-1248069043992">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Chaiwali
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
On two lovingly decorated floors of a Harlem brownstone, this restaurant serves the relaxed, light-handed, modern food that Americans with roots in India may cook at home.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/04/27/dining/27REST-slide-6RPD/27REST-slide-6RPD-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-04-27T00:00:00">April 27, 2016</time>

<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/27/dining/chaiwali-review-indian-food-harlem.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</li>

</ul>
</footer>

</h2>

<li class="critics-pick">

<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chinatown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

<li id="story-id-1248069043983-21">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/23/dining/hungry-city-angkor-cambodian-bistro-upper-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Angkor Cambodian Bistro
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Southeast Asian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Upper East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Low lights and dark wood, paintings of temples half-eaten by jungle, the interior gaze of a long-lobed Buddha head: Angkor is handsome and hushed, far from the brimming-over refugee camp in Thailand where Minh Truong, the chef, first learned to cook. His dishes are gently spiced, many harking back to the Thai restaurant he ran in Chelsea for two decades; the best draw from his mother’s Cambodian recipes.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/03/23/dining/23HUNGRY-ANGKOR-slide-FRG0/23HUNGRY-ANGKOR-slide-FRG0-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-03-23T00:00:00">March 23, 2016</time>

<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/23/dining/hungry-city-angkor-cambodian-bistro-upper-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069043979">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/09/dining/hungry-city-yaso-tangbao-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Yaso Tangbao
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Downtown Brooklyn</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Nearly everything on the menu at this informal restaurant summons up the streets of Shanghai, from the giant shaggy pork-belly meatballs called lion's heads, majestic and mystifyingly airy, to volcanic soup dumplings from a chef who made his name at the first Joe's Shanghai in Flushing, Queens.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/03/09/dining/09HUNGRY-YASO-slide-PVQG/09HUNGRY-YASO-slide-PVQG-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-03-09T00:00:00">March 9, 2016</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/09/dining/hungry-city-yaso-tangbao-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>
</li>
<li id="story-id-1248069043978">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/02/dining/hungry-city-leche-y-miel-restaurant-the-bronx.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Leche y Miel Restaurant
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Caribbean, Latin American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Kingsbridge</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Rideiby Peña, the chef of Leche y Miel, and his wife, Altagracia Peña, both have roots in the Dominican Republic, as do the finest dishes here.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

<li id="story-id-1248069043977">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/24/dining/little-pepper-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Little Pepper
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">College Point</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The chefs excel at bringing the fiery flavors of Sichuan cuisine into balance with sweet, salty and sour ones.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043975">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/24/dining/hungry-city-oatmeals-greenwich-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
OatMeals
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenwich Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
If the quaint, wholesome scene is expected at OatMeals, the 30-odd variations of oatmeal are not, including bowls — sized in Baby Bear, Mama Bear and Papa Bear, of course — topped with the likes of bacon, truffle oil, coconut milk, sriracha and Gruyère. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/02/24/dining/24HUNGRY-slide-6GCZ/24HUNGRY-slide-6GCZ-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-02-24T00:00:00">Feb. 24, 2016</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/24/dining/hungry-city-oatmeals-greenwich-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>

<li id="story-id-1248069043973">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/17/dining/hungry-city-kichin-williamsburg-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Kichin
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Korean</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Kichin, a mostly Korean, mostly takeout shop under the Marcy Avenue L train stop, the young chef Bryan Moon champions the dishes of his childhood and invents a few of his own, including a rice ball prickly with bacon shards, hiding a soft-boiled quail egg at its center.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/02/17/dining/17HUNGRY-KITCHEN-slide-FUXT/17HUNGRY-KITCHEN-slide-FUXT-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-02-17T00:00:00">Feb. 17, 2016</time>

<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Pizza Moto @ John Grace Bakery
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Pizza</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Red Hook</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
A pizzeria in the Brooklyn-Neapolitan tradition exemplified by Roberta’s and Franny’s, Pizza Moto makes excellent use of a restored oven.
</p>

By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
East Coast Poké
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">West Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Brooklyn-born Alfred DiMartini, a former line cook at Lupa and Bouley, makes fine, honest poke, without too many complications.
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043972-22">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/10/dining/llama-inn-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Llama Inn
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Latin American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Llama Inn’s careful kitchen is interpreting the cuisine of Peru, whose vast catalog of ingredients and wild juxtapositions of influences have not been especially well displayed in New York.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043967">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/03/dining/hungry-city-africa-kine-harlem.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Africa Kine
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">African</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Harlem</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Samba Niang and Kine (pronounced kee-nay) Mar, natives of Dakar, run this Senegalese restaurant in Harlem, where by day, women cook crowded, fragrant stews, primed with fermented dried fish and sea snail; men roast monuments of meat by night.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/02/03/dining/03HUNGARY-AFRICAKINE-slide-JXR8/03HUNGARY-AFRICAKINE-slide-JXR8-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-02-03T00:00:00">Feb. 3, 2016</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Pravue Cafe and Albanian Grill
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Pravue Cafe in Ridgewood, Queens, the menu alternates between dishes that look to the West and those that stay true to Albania, made from recipes passed down through generations.

<li id="story-id-1248069043964">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/20/dining/hungry-city-taste-of-samarkand-uzbek-restaurant-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Taste of Samarkand
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>




<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Middle Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Don’t be dissuaded by this Uzbek restaurant’s unassuming exterior. Inside is an arbor, with dangling grapes and leaves, and a menu with plenty to please, including improbably airy samsa (meat pastries), soups exhaling dill and kebabs that are hot gulps of salt and smoke.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Manila Social Club
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>

<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Manila Social Club in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, harks back to the chef Björn DelaCruz's grandmother’s home in Davao Oriental, the Philippines, with orchids arcing from the windowsills, and nostalgia likewise suffuses the best dishes.
