<li id="story-id-1248069043956">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/09/dining/hungry-city-kopitiam-lower-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Kopitiam
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Malaysian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This tiny counter spot, with four stools, is a loving homage to the Malaysian kopitiam, or coffee shop, where the chef Kyo Pang, hopes to keep alive the Baba-Nyonya art of snacks, passed down by descendants of Chinese settlers along the Straits of Malacca.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069043954">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/02/dining/hungry-city-amaranto-bushwick-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Amaranto
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Bushwick</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Fermin Teco, the chef at this outwardly placid, modest family-run Mexican restaurant in a former corner bodega, has a gentle way with ingredients that allows flavors to emerge decorously rather than shove themselves forward.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-12-02T00:00:00">Dec. 2, 2015</time>

<li id="story-id-1248069043950">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/18/dining/hungry-city-bago-tito-kings-kitchen-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Tito King’s Kitchen at Jimmy’s No. 43
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian, Philippine</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Tito King’s, a restaurant-in-residence at Jimmy’s No. 43, the brief menu includes chicken wings braised in adobo; pork belly in tacos; a grass-fed burger with a trickle of Maggi sauce; and a take on disco fries with ground pork, Kewpie mayonnaise and dancing bonito flakes doing the Hustle.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043944">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/28/dining/hungry-city-timna-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Timna
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mediterranean</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Timna’s chef, Nir Mesika, grew up in Israel, and his cooking is at its strongest when he draws from memory, as with kubaneh, a Yemenite-Jewish bread somewhere between brioche and challah, or a simple dish of vegetables and farro laced with raw tahini and date molasses.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/10/28/dining/28HUNGRY-TIMNA-slide-AEZL/28HUNGRY-TIMNA-slide-AEZL-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069043942">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/21/dining/hungry-city-asian-spicy-curry-chinatown.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Asian Spicy Curry
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Malaysian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chinatown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Yip Khuan Thye, a native of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, takes over the kitchen of Mama Eatery in Chinatown; the curries on the nocturnal pop-up menu are priced at $6 or $7, each a small world.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/21/dining/restaurant-review-bruno-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Bruno Pizza
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-word-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="2">

<span class="visually-hidden"></span>

Satisfactory
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Italian, Pizza</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Bruno’s chefs, Justin Slojkowski and Dave Gulino, mill the flour for their pizza dough in the basement, and serve pies that don't play it safe.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Momofuku Ko
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>

<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian, French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The new Momofuku Ko restaurant is not an experiment, but rather a statement of what fancy dining has become, in large part due to the influence of the original.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043940">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/07/dining/hungry-city-safari-somali-restaurant-harlem.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Safari
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">African</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Harlem</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Safari, there are fine heaps of meat, underscored by African birdseye chiles; influences from across the gulf and the Arabian Sea; and turmeric-tinged rice nestled companionably beside pasta in a quasi-Alfredo sauce of coconut and cow’s milks, imbued with oregano, rosemary and basil — a legacy of Somalia’s half-century of Italian occupation.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/10/07/dining/07HUNGRY-SAFARI-slide-C97U/07HUNGRY-SAFARI-slide-C97U-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-10-07T00:00:00">Oct. 7, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/07/dining/hungry-city-safari-somali-restaurant-harlem.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069043941-25">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/07/dining/restaurant-review-wildair-on-the-lower-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Wildair
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The chefs Jeremiah Stone and Fabian von Hauske serve familiar, likeable food at this wine bar two doors down Orchard Street from their showcase restaurant, Contra.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043938">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/30/dining/hungry-city-goa-taco-lower-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Goa Taco
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>




<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Goa Taco's offerings are half-moon in shape, but in lieu of a thin, pliant tortilla, fillings — Chinese five-spice duck confit, say, or Oaxacan-style achiote lamb with Greek tzatziki — are trapped inside paratha, a many-layered Indian flatbread built like a chapbook of dough, each leaf inscribed with ghee.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/09/30/dining/30HUNGRY-GOA-TACO-slide-MBHF/30HUNGRY-GOA-TACO-slide-MBHF-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-09-30T00:00:00">Sept. 30, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/30/dining/hungry-city-goa-taco-lower-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>

<li id="story-id-1248069043939">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/30/dining/restaurant-review-houseman-in-hudson-square.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Houseman
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Hudson Square</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
You don’t taste Houseman’s food in politely appreciative nibbles, you throw yourself at it until there’s nothing left. No menu layout can convey this quality, but when you find a restaurant that has it, you come back.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/09/30/dining/30REST-HOUSEMAN-slide-TZLS/30REST-HOUSEMAN-slide-TZLS-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069043937">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/23/dining/restaurant-review-gabriel-kreuther-in-midtown.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Gabriel Kreuther
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Gabriel Kreuther named his new restaurant on 42nd Street after himself, but it could just as easily be called the Modern in Exile, as he took along that restaurant's pastry chef and replicated its two-in-one structure.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043936">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/23/dining/hungry-city-lucys-vietnamese-kitchen-bushwick-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Lucy’s Vietnamese Kitchen
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Vietnamese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Bushwick</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Lucy’s Vietnamese Kitchen, pho chay has a bold near-funk from long-simmering shiitake mushrooms, charred shallots, ginger and a suffusion of spices, and while the broth, as crystalline as consommé, is lovely in its pristine state, it is even better besmirched by brisket that has been smoked for 14 hours.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/09/23/dining/23HUNGRY-LUCYS-slide-H3KT/23HUNGRY-LUCYS-slide-H3KT-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-09-23T00:00:00">Sept. 23, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/23/dining/hungry-city-lucys-vietnamese-kitchen-bushwick-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>

<li id="story-id-1075197022910">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/16/dining/restaurant-review-casa-mono-gramercy.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Casa Mono
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Spanish</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Gramercy Park</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Anthony Sasso, the chef de cuisine, has led the Casa Mono kitchen into cooking that a Catalan tapas-bar proprietor might squint at before deciding that tapas do not always need to be interpreted with a strict-constructionist approach.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Babu Ji
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Indian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Babu Ji’s menu is succinct rather than sprawling, with Indian food that is remarkably fresh and light.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">

<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan

<li id="story-id-1248069043933">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/02/dining/restaurant-review-superiority-burger-in-the-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Superiority Burger
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Vegan</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
New ideas fly through Superiority Burger’s kitchen so quickly you can almost hear them buzz by, which is what elevates the place above what it appears to be at first glance, a Shake Shack for vegetarians.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/09/02/dining/02REST-slide-4TAI/02REST-slide-4TAI-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Food Sermon
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>

</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Caribbean</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Crown Heights</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
A theology-school dropout who found salvation in the kitchen, Rawlston Williams, the chef at the Food Sermon, has a particular gift for meat, achieving tenderness without surrendering flavor.
</p>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Clocktower
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">English, French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown South</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The Clocktower plays a familiar game, the private club that has accidentally let you in, but the cooking of Jason Atherton, an English chef who worked under Gordon Ramsay, has the peculiar idea of cooking to make other people happy, not to reflect his own glory.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

Oiji
</h2>

<li id="story-id-1248069043927">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/05/dining/hungry-city-chicks-to-go-in-the-rockaways.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Chicks To Go
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Latin American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">The Rockaways</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this Peruvian pollería (rotisserie-chicken shop) a block from the beach, chicken is saturated for half a day with cumin, oregano, garlic, soy and smoky aji panca pepper, then turned over flame until the skin blisters and shimmers and the juices run mad within. Some of the meat is destined for aji gallina, a creamy stew that is all the more luxurious when it spills out of an otherwise ordinary-looking empanada; or for chaufa, from the Chinese chao fan (fried rice), even better made with quinoa grown in Peru.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/05/dining/20150805HUNGRY-slide-KH43/20150805HUNGRY-slide-KH43-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-08-05T00:00:00">Aug. 5, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/05/dining/hungry-city-chicks-to-go-in-the-rockaways.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>

<li id="story-id-1248069043827">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
El Rey Coffee Bar &amp; Luncheonette
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">

<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Mexican, Vegetarian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Gerardo Gonzalez has has worked out a point of view in the El Rey kitchen that is distinctly his own, a blend of California-Mexican cuisine with some of the less punitive flavors from the health-food and vegan disciplines.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">

<span class="author-name">

<li id="story-id-1248069043926">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/29/dining/hungry-city-langos-truck.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Langos Truck
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">European</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
If you are Hungarian, this is the taste of summer: langos (pronounced LAHN-gauche), a rough disc of fried flatbread, cracker-crisp along the circumference and chewier toward the center, where it approaches gooeyness. At the Langos Truck, Zsolt Prepuk, a native of Budapest, also serves sandwiches of Mangalitsa pork sausages, in honor of the woolly Hungarian pigs bred to feed Hapsburg emperors, whose lushly marbled meat is likened to Kobe beef.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/07/29/fashion/20150729HUNGRY-slide-L978/20150729HUNGRY-slide-L978-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-07-29T00:00:00">July 29, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/29/dining/hungry-city-langos-truck.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Kiki’s
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Greek</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chinatown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Kiki's menu is littered with words like “classic,” “uncomplicated” and “childhood,” all to the good, and it is the kind of place where fresh carafes of water are plonked on the table even after the bill has been settled and you’re allowed — invited — to idle.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069043922">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/15/dining/hungry-city-the-handpulled-noodle-in-harlem.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Handpulled Noodle
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Harlem</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The hand-pulled noodles at this counter-seating-only restaurant come from Xinjiang, in China’s far northwest, and they are denser and rougher than the more widely known Lanzhou-style hand-pulled noodles found in Chinatown, and fantastically chewy; Andrew Ding, the owner, was born in Urumqi and raised in Sydney, Australia -- both parts of the world share a love of lamb, and that meat is what gives contour and depth to the finest dishes here.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/07/15/dining/20150715HUNGRY-slide-LPHS/20150715HUNGRY-slide-LPHS-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-07-15T00:00:00">July 15, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/15/dining/hungry-city-the-handpulled-noodle-in-harlem.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>

<li id="story-id-1248069043921">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/08/dining/hungry-city-the-happiest-hour-in-greenwich-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Happiest Hour
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenwich Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
It’s all about the burger at this vaguely tropical spot in Greenwich Village, and the Happiest Burger, a blatant homage to the California-born In-N-Out burger, is the showstopper.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Jeff Gordinier
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/07/08/dining/20150708HUNGRY-slide-NE02/20150708HUNGRY-slide-NE02-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">

<li id="story-id-1248069043919">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/24/dining/restaurant-reviews-noreetuh-the-eddy-in-the-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Noreetuh
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
With prime ingredients, carefully organized plates and nonviolent prices, Noreetuh tries to tidy up Hawaiian dishes like garlic shrimp and tuna poke for their introduction to New York. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043920">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/24/dining/restaurant-reviews-noreetuh-the-eddy-in-the-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Eddy
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The Eddy is one of those restaurants that gets so many little details right that your main course can be a little shaky and you can still walk out happy.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043363-27">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/17/dining/restaurant-review-blanca-in-bushwick-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Blanca
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Bushwick</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Carlo Mirarchi, the chef and owner of Blanca and its sprawling mothership, Roberta’s, is a rigorous miniaturist, combining a few ingredients at a time into two or three-bite compositions that are utterly complete, even if they leave you wanting more; over the years he has steadily refined his marathon tastings, and nearly everything served is remarkable in one way or another.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/06/17/dining/20150617REST-slide-VO50/20150617REST-slide-VO50-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-06-17T00:00:00">June 17, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/17/dining/restaurant-review-blanca-in-bushwick-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

<li>
<a class="reserve-table" href="https://www.yelpreservations.com/r/blanca/" target="_blank" title="Reserve a Table">Reserve a Table</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069043917">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/17/dining/hungry-city-i-love-paraguay-restaurant-in-sunnyside-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
I Love Paraguay
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Latin American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Sunnyside</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
I Love Paraguay started out as a bakery and Nancy Ojeda’s desserts, assembled in a case at the back, are still the main attraction, particularly mousse maracuja; the best entrees are the most traditional, like mbeju, a meld of cassava starch, milk, eggs and Muenster that suggests a further step in the evolution of a quesadilla, and chipa guazu, a savory cake sweetened with whole corn kernels and teetering on soufflé. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/06/17/dining/20150617HUNGRY-slide-8ADX/20150617HUNGRY-slide-8ADX-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-06-17T00:00:00">June 17, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/17/dining/hungry-city-i-love-paraguay-restaurant-in-sunnyside-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

<li id="story-id-1248069043247">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/10/dining/restaurant-review-mission-chinese-food-on-the-lower-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Mission Chinese Food
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Idiosyncrasy is to Mission Chinese Food what the Bloomin’ Onion is to an Outback Steakhouse, and at its new location, the restaurant's menu is more varied than before, drawing from regions beyond Sichuan and countries beyond China.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Okonomi
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Japanese breakfast is the specialty here, served until afternoon as a set menu that includes rice, miso soup, pickled vegetables, a choice of fish and two amuse-bouche-size sides.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan

<li id="story-id-1248069043915">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/03/dining/hungry-city-punda-tibetan-sunnyside-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Punda Tibetan
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Tibetan</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Sunnyside</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Punda Tibetan's menu, with just three dishes over $10, is nomadic in spirit, but the best dishes — momos (dumplings), soups of remarkable clarity, beef sautés of alternating brightness and heat — are the ones identified as Tibetan.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043914">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/27/dining/hungry-city-crepes-canaveral-restaurant-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Crêpes Canaveral
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this takeout stand the size of a carnival ticket booth, Jean-Christophe Henry makes Breton crepes from a family recipe that dates back to the late 19th century, and he encourages customers to eat inside the adjacent William Barnacle Tavern, to which Crêpes Canaveral is attached, a low-key, Celtic-leaning bar that was once the taproom of a Prohibition-era speakeasy and still looks it.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/27/dining/20150527HUNGRY-slide-I8O2/20150527HUNGRY-slide-I8O2-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-05-27T00:00:00">May 27, 2015</time>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Aquavit
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>

<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>

<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown East</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Aquavit's kitchen is soaring, with Emma Bengtsson, the chef, cooking modern Scandinavian cuisine without aping the fashionable Nordic tropes.

Pete Wells

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Javelina
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-word-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

<li id="story-id-1248069043912">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/20/dining/hungry-city-kottu-house-sri-lanka-restaurant-lower-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Kottu House
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">




<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Kottu House, Chelaka Gunamuni, a young man in stubbly beard and tattoos (one a birthday gift from his wife), tends to the front of the house while his mother, Sandya “Madu” De Silva, cooks a short menu focused on kottu, a Sri Lankan street food that tosses together tatters of roti, scrambled eggs and long-simmering curry.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/20/dining/20150520HUNGRY-slide-SRL0/20150520HUNGRY-slide-SRL0-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-05-20T00:00:00">May 20, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/20/dining/hungry-city-kottu-house-sri-lanka-restaurant-lower-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>
</li>
<li id="story-id-1248069043911">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/13/dining/buried-treasures-at-raclette.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Raclette
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this tiny storefront, the melting surface of great half-wheels of raclette cheese is scraped down tableside over a plate of cornichons, pickled pearl onions, roasted potatoes and thin, purplish-red slices of air-dried beef. It is deeply satisfying to watch the cascade of cheese and to dig out the vegetables and meat below, as if eating fondue in reverse.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/13/dining/20150513HUNGRY-slide-M7LP/20150513HUNGRY-slide-M7LP-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-05-07T12:40:47">May 7, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/13/dining/buried-treasures-at-raclette.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>

<li id="story-id-1248069043909-28">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/06/dining/hungry-city-hanyang-bunsik-flushing-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
HanYang BunSik
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Korean</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Flushing</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
HanYang BunSik's dishes fall under the Korean category of bunsik, or snacks, including blood sausage embedded with sticky rice, kabocha porridge and a skewered hot dog with an airy crust of panko, like a corn dog from the fairy realm.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/06/dining/20150506HUNGRY-slide-B2UZ/20150506HUNGRY-slide-B2UZ-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069043910">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/06/dining/restaurant-review-mu-ramen-in-long-island-city-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Mu Ramen
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Japanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Long Island City</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Of all the restaurants in the city where you are expected to make loud slurping noises while you eat, Joshua and Heidy Smookler’s Mu Ramen may be the most civilized. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043908">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/29/dining/hungry-city-east-wind-snack-shop-in-windsor-terrace-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
East Wind Snack Shop
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Windsor Terrace</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
East Wind Snack Shop is a modern homage to Chinatown’s bygone working-class coffee houses, cramped, dingy storefronts offering unlimited tea and limited food, with plastic fans stuttering above, strategically hung fly paper and a lot of (happy) yelling between tables.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/29/dining/20150429HUNGRY-slide-IQEM/20150429HUNGRY-slide-IQEM-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-04-29T00:00:00">April 29, 2015</time>

<li id="story-id-1248069043775">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Minton’s 
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Southern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Harlem</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The kitchen is a little unpredictable, and the success of dinner at Minton’s depends on how much you like to hear jazz musicians skittering around a tune, toying with a rhythm, tying and untying knots of harmony.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043906">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/22/dining/hungry-city-casa-del-chef-in-woodside-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Casa Del Chef
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">New American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Woodside</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Casa Del Chef's food — the kind of thoughtful farm-to-table cooking now standard in other parts of the city but still a rarity in this neighborhood — is rooted in the country its chef and owner, Alfonso Zhicay, now calls home.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Estiatorio Milos
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Greek</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Since 1997, Milos has served Greek cuisine, particularly whole fish and shellfish kept on ice near the open kitchen, to loyal customers who can afford the forbidding prices.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043904">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/08/dining/restaurant-reviews-limani-and-estiatorio-milos-in-midtown.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Limani
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Greek, Seafood</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Limani’s menu is Greek and its strength is formidably expensive seafood, which up until the moment it is laid on the grill can be found spread out on a small mountain of ice at the edge of the open kitchen.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043903">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/08/dining/hungry-city-spaha-soul-in-east-harlem.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
SpaHa Soul
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Harlem</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
“This is the most informal dining experience you’ll ever have,” said Artist Thornton, the owner and “chef” (quotation marks his) of this idiosyncratic and lovely little restaurant; the food, which traverses Louisiana, Mexico and India, has an improvised feel, with dishes made for (and named after) neighbors and friends.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/08/dining/20150408HUNGRY-slide-UNVH/20150408HUNGRY-slide-UNVH-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-04-08T00:00:00">April 8, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/08/dining/hungry-city-spaha-soul-in-east-harlem.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>

<li id="story-id-1248069043902">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/01/dining/hungry-city-masha-the-bear-in-east-williamsburg-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Masha &amp; the Bear
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Russian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Masha and the Bear, the horseradish vodka is infused in-house and stored in pressurized kegs to avoid exposure to air; Anya Vasilenko, the chef, cleaves to tradition with dishes like ukha, a fish soup purportedly beloved by Ivan the Terrible, and Herring in a Fur Coat, a salad born of the Russian Revolution, uniting proletarian herring and peasant potatoes under a mantle of beets in Bolshevik red.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/01/dining/20150401HUNGRY-slide-IIPF/20150401HUNGRY-slide-IIPF-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-04-01T00:00:00">April 1, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/01/dining/hungry-city-masha-the-bear-in-east-williamsburg-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>

<li id="story-id-1248069043900-29">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/25/dining/hungry-city-haldi-in-midtown-south.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Haldi
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Indian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Kips Bay</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Haldi’s menu is a delightful compendium of cultural references to the city of Kolkata in West Bengal, India, drawing on the culinary traditions of Bengalis, the British Raj, Marwari migrants from Rajasthan, Kolkata’s Chinatown (the birthplace of Indian Chinese cuisine) and the city’s small but once influential community of Baghdadi Jews. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/03/25/dining/20150325HUNGRY-slide-0U9B/20150325HUNGRY-slide-0U9B-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Little Park
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">

<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">TriBeCa</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Little Park, Andrew Carmellini and his chef de cuisine, Min Kong, are working out their ideas from scratch; this may be why the best dishes there seem more fresh, natural and intuitive than what’s on Mr. Carmellini's other menus.
</p>

Pete Wells

</h2>

<li id="story-id-1248069043898">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/11/dining/restaurant-review-bowery-meat-company-in-the-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Bowery Meat Company
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Steak Houses</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The chef Josh Capon and the restaurateur John McDonald, the pair behind Lure Fishbar and El Toro Blanco, have brought forth a “meat company” whose website says it is “not a traditional steakhouse, but a balanced meat-centric menu.” Bowery Meat Company is not, in fact, a menu. But it does have a menu, and on it you will find seven cuts of beef plus a burger, potatoes cooked four ways, and a spinach side dish. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043897">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/11/dining/hungry-city-house-of-inasal-in-woodside-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
House of Inasal
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Philippine</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Woodside</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This Filipino restaurant, in a stretch of Queens known as Little Manila, feels spacious and sleepy, operating at the pace of a desultory ceiling fan. The menu is congenial, offering unlimited rice, all-day breakfast and street specialties like grilled pork intestines and kwek-kwek (deep-fried quail eggs).
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069043895">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/04/dining/hungry-city-la-morada-in-the-south-bronx.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
La Morada
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">North New York</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
La Morada’s married owners, Natalia Mendez and Antonio Saavedra, were once farmers in Oaxaca, which is one of the poorest states in Mexico but whose cuisine is among the country’s richest. While much of the menu is taken up by tacos and quesadillas, a few dishes offer a glimpse of the “infinite gastronomy” that is Oaxacan cooking.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069043896">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/04/dining/restaurant-review-via-carota-in-the-west-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Via Carota
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Italian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">West Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Jody Williams, who shares responsibility for Via Carota’s Italian menu with Rita Sodi, has filled Via Carota with flea-market triumphs that give the dining room an ambient level of cuteness that is balanced by an Italian severity. The two chefs cook food that is deeply appealing, without mugging. Ms. Sodi is a stickler about the pastas; like the meat and fish dishes, they aren’t any more complicated than they need to be.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/03/04/dining/20150304REST-slide-93SG/20150304REST-slide-93SG-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-03-04T00:00:00">March 4, 2015</time>

</ul>

<li id="story-id-1248069043893">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/25/dining/izakaya-in-the-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Izakaya
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
An izakaya is an informal Japanese establishment, neither quite restaurant nor tavern, that treats eating as fortification for drinking. But Dai Watanabe, the chef here, is not content to be an accompanist. The mission may be comfort food, but there’s a reverence to its making, even in the minor dishes. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/02/25/dining/20150225HUNGRY-slide-QMLO/20150225HUNGRY-slide-QMLO-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-02-25T00:00:00">Feb. 25, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/25/dining/izakaya-in-the-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>

</footer>

<li id="story-id-1248069043891">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/18/dining/patacon-pisao-on-the-lower-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Patacon Pisao
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Latin American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The specialty here is patacón, the formidable sandwich of the city of Maracaibo, Venezuela, bookended not by bread but by unripe plantains that have been fried, smashed and fried again. The small but sleek storefront traces its origins back to 2005, when Liliana Velazquez, a native of Maracaibo, started selling patacónes out of a truck in Inwood, Manhattan
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/02/18/dining/20150218HUNGRY-slide-QMC1/20150218HUNGRY-slide-QMC1-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-02-18T00:00:00">Feb. 18, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/18/dining/patacon-pisao-on-the-lower-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>

<li id="story-id-1248069043892">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/18/dining/restaurant-review-shuko-in-the-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Shuko
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenwich Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Jimmy Lau and Nick Kim, the chefs and owners, rose to the top of Masa Takayama’s restaurant group. What’s impressive about their own restaurant, Shuko, is how many times the chefs ring the bells without resorting to clichéd indulgences.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/02/18/dining/20150218REST-slide-9N31/20150218REST-slide-9N31-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
