<li id="story-id-1248069043889-30">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/11/dining/hungry-city-patina-in-morrisania-the-bronx.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Patina
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">African</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Fairmont - Claremont Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
It can be an intimate, if slightly disorienting experience dining at this very small West African restaurant in the Bronx. No menu is presented, at least not in written form, and only a few dishes are available at a time. But the food is delicious: earthy soups and stews over dense, chewy rice and black-eyed peas, with seams of heat from hidden Scotch bonnets.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/02/11/dining/20150211HUNGRY-slide-RZKG/20150211HUNGRY-slide-RZKG-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-02-11T00:00:00">Feb. 11, 2015</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/11/dining/hungry-city-patina-in-morrisania-the-bronx.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069043888">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/04/dining/restaurant-review-cosme-in-the-flatiron-district.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Cosme
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Modernist</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Flatiron</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The first New York restaurant from the acclaimed Mexican chef Enrique Olvera pulls off two tough moves at once. First, its approach to Mexican cuisine is modern and relaxed, but without the superficiality that might imply. Second, it has a sharp instinct for what New Yorkers want when they go out for dinner, which isn’t often the case with restaurants opened by chefs from abroad.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
PETE WELLS
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/02/04/dining/20150204REST-slide-XBD1/20150204REST-slide-XBD1-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</div><!-- close story-body -->

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Sariling Atin
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Philippine</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Elmhurst</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Past the shelves of egg cracklets and adobo-flavored corn nuts at Sariling Atin is a modest dining room, where food is ordered turo-turo (point-point) style, as in a cafeteria, and spooned into plastic-foam bowls. 
</p>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Blue Smoke

<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Kips Bay</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Since opening in 2002, Blue Smoke has always been a few paces behind the frontrunners of New York barbecue. But when it comes to contemporary Southern cooking, Jean-Paul Bourgeois’s menu is at the head of the pack. 
</p>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
LoLo’s Seafood Shack
</h2>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Behind the frosted windows of LoLo’s Seafood Shack, the extemporaneous spirit of the lolo — the kind of open-air barbecue joint found on the beaches and roadsides of St. Martin in the West Indies — is strong.
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043884">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/21/dining/hungry-city-plant-love-house-in-elmhurst-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Plant Love House
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Thai</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Elmhurst</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this cheerful, unassuming storefront, Manadsanan Sutipayakul is cooking for the neighborhood: the clientele is mostly Thai, the dishes comforting rather than showy. Her daughters make the desserts, which include sizzling platters designed to make you gasp or giggle.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069043882">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/14/dining/hungry-city-blvd-bistro-in-harlem.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
BLVD Bistro
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Southern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Harlem</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Carlos Swepson, a New York chef with roots in Natchez, Miss., is not reinventing the Southern-food wheel, but he is trying to make it a smoother ride. His best food — like wood-smoked chicken, crisp wild grouper with a cornmeal crust, and exemplary Southern potato salad (with chopped hard-boiled eggs) — is pressed right up against tradition, but tweaked for modern taste.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Julia Moskin
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069043883">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/14/dining/restaurant-review-upland-on-park-avenue-south.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Upland
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Kips Bay</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Upland occupies the middle ground, a big restaurant that has enough set dressing to feel like an event without competing with the food. The chef Justin Smillie splashes around in the gentle, sun-dappled river of classic California cuisine. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
PETE WELLS
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069043881">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/07/dining/restaurant-review-kappo-masa-on-the-upper-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Kappo Masa
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-word-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="2">

<span class="visually-hidden"></span>

Satisfactory
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Upper East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The chef Masa Takayama, who owns this restaurant with the art dealer Larry Gagosian, is known for sushi, of course, but Kappo Masa presents a general overview of Japanese cuisine. The cost of eating at Kappo Masa is so brutally, illogically, relentlessly high, and so out of proportion to any pleasure you might get, that the prices become inescapable companions of your meal.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
PETE WELLS
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/01/07/dining/20150107-REST-slide-5V6Z/20150107-REST-slide-5V6Z-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">

</li>

<li id="story-id-1248069043878-31">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/24/dining/hungry-city-the-halal-guys.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Halal Guys
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Middle Eastern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
It started as a nameless food cart on 53rd Street and Avenue of the Americas serving platters of lamb and chicken. Today this business, officially named the Halal Guys, comprises four carts and two restaurants in New York, with franchises set to open around the country and abroad.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">

<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Elmhurst</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Lily Tjia started cooking, semi-secretly, for her neighbors in the growing Indonesian community of South Philadelphia. In 2010 she opened a restaurant in that city; four year later, she moved to Elmhurst, Queens, and opened another.

<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese</li>

<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

<li id="story-id-1248069043876">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/10/dining/restaurant-review-dirty-french-on-the-lower-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Dirty French
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
What if nouvelle cuisine had embraced maximalism instead of minimalism, full-frontal abandon instead of lean precision? The result might be something like Dirty French, where the chefs Rich Torrisi and Mario Carbone treat the food of France with a hugely energizing lack of respect.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
PETE WELLS
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069043873">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/03/dining/hungry-city-fitzcarraldo-in-east-williamsburg-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Fitzcarraldo
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Italian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
A kind of magical loneliness possesses Fitzcarraldo, which occupies a corner of a 30,000-square-foot former warehouse in the East Williamsburg In-Place Industrial Park. The food is Italian, mostly Ligurian, and lovely, with one of the best renditions of cacio e pepe in town.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043874">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/03/dining/restaurant-review-danny-meyers-marta-in-nomad.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Marta
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Italian, Pizza</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown South</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Pizza, a lesser stop on Rome’s culinary pilgrimage route, is the main event of this pizzeria, opened by the chef Nick Anderer. Marta has Roman appetizers and entire Roman dishes repurposed as toppings for pizzas with thin crusts in the Roman style. Main courses are available, but they are not as trustworthy as the pies. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
PETE WELLS
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043812">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/26/dining/restaurant-review-bar-bolonat-in-the-west-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Bar Bolonat
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Middle Eastern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">West Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The white napkins, polished stemware, sheer curtains and understated modern furniture at Bar Bolonat are all a determined bid for the kinds of diners who would steer clear of anything resembling a hummus hut. Energetic seasoning drives the cuisine, and can be seen in dishes like shrimp in a Yemenite curry, with a fiery shot of green zhug and a small round of fried bread called malawa to soak up the spicy, turmeric-gold coconut milk.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
PETE WELLS
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Carnitas El Atoradero
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Mott Haven</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Denisse Lina Chavez, the chef and owner of Carnitas El Atoradero, cooked carnitas in her bodega next door to growing crowds. Now, with a proper kitchen, she makes daily specials with traditional herbs and spices shipped by her sister from Mexico. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069043871">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/12/dining/restaurant-review-dumpling-galaxy-in-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Dumpling Galaxy
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Flushing</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Sturdy, knobby, domestic creatures in the Northern Chinese tradition, Helen You's dumplings are stuffed to order, and she fine-tunes them with the sensitivity of a natural cook who really listens to her ingredients. At Dumpling Galaxy, she offers 100 varieties, along with an additional menu of dishes from Hunan, Dongbei and Fujian.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
PETE WELLS
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/11/12/dining/20141112-REST-slide-NKBJ/20141112-REST-slide-NKBJ-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2014-11-12T00:00:00">Nov. 12, 2014</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/12/dining/restaurant-review-dumpling-galaxy-in-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>

<li id="story-id-1248069043870">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/12/dining/hungry-city-hard-times-sundaes-in-mill-basin-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Hard Times Sundaes
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Mill Basin</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this food truck parked behind a Walgreen’s in Mill Basin, a neighborhood in southernmost Brooklyn, the meat is fresh ground chuck, not some proprietary blend of dry-aged Black Angus cuts.  For non-locals, the journey here — by subway, then bus — is long, and worth it. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/11/12/dining/20141112-HUNGRY-slide-19MJ/20141112-HUNGRY-slide-19MJ-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2014-11-12T00:00:00">Nov. 12, 2014</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>

<li id="story-id-1248069043869-32">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/05/dining/restaurant-review-tuome-in-the-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Tuome
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
You have probably eaten in dozens of rooms like Tuome in the past few years, and eaten dishes that look like the ones that the chef, Thomas Chen, is sending from the kitchen. Once the meal begins, though, it becomes clear that Mr. Chen has originality to spare and a clear, fresh point of view, particularly when he interprets Chinese cuisine.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
PETE WELLS
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/29/dining/restaurant-review-blue-hill-in-greenwich-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Blue Hill
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">New American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenwich Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The chef Dan Barber is a dirt poet and kitchen philosopher whose time with the pigs and the beans has had a deep, lasting effect on the way he cooks; New York City does not afford the time or space for the leisurely unfurling of Mr. Barber’s complete vision, but Blue Hill is still an exceptional restaurant.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
PETE WELLS
</span>
</p>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Bao
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>

<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this Manhattan outpost of Kung Fu Xiao Long Bao, in Flushing, Queens,  the menu is greatest-hits Chinese, corralling Sichuan flamethrowers with old-school Cantonese.

<li id="story-id-1248069043867">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/22/dining/restaurant-review-blenheim-in-the-west-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Blenheim
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Modernist</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">West Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
A tremendous amount of thought and effort has gone into Blenheim’s food, drinks and design, but the pieces don’t always fit together. When tables are set up outside next to the cobblestoned streets, Blenheim looks as if its only desire is to be your drop-in-and-hang-out corner tavern. But the food, as imagined by the chef Ryan Tate, has as much business in a rusticated farm-to-table tavern as white tie and spats.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
PETE WELLS
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

Phimploy Likitsansook has brought over a few of her secrets from her Hell’s Kitchen restaurant Wondee Siam, but the execution is more focused, the contours of flavor more distinct, and a few dishes approach greatness.

Arepa Lady
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>

<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Corona</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
For more than two decades, Maria Piedad Cano, a.k.a. the Arepa Lady, has parked her cart among the late-night roisterers of Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens. Now her arepas are available at normal waking hours, at a small restaurant. 
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043862">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/08/dining/rice-and-noodles-in-many-guises-.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Com Tam Ninh Kieu 
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Vietnamese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Kingsbridge Heights</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The specialty at Com Tam Ninh Kieu in the Bronx, a Vietnamese restaurant,  is broken rice, grains splintered in the milling process, clingier and earthier than their grander, polished cousins. The rest of the menu consists almost entirely of noodle soups.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043863">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/08/dining/restaurant-review-huertas-in-the-east-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Huertas
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Spanish</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Huertas is really two restaurants and two experiences under one roof. In the back is a small, square dining room where the chef, Jonah Miller, serves a set menu of five courses. In the front of the restaurant is an inviting tapas bar, where a different style of eating unfolds. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
PETE WELLS
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043860">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/01/dining/hungry-city-old-tbilisi-garden-in-greenwich-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Old Tbilisi Garden
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Eastern European, Russian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenwich Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Old Tbilisi Garden offers subtle pleasures of Georgian food, dishes suffused with summer savory, coriander, marigold and blue fenugreek. And it has adjaruli khachapuri, a thick flatbread with the ends tapered into blunt handles and the middle a cauldron of near-volcanic cheese, with a yolk slowly setting on top. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/10/01/dining/20141001-HUNGRY-slide-HM6D/20141001-HUNGRY-slide-HM6D-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2014-10-01T00:00:00">Oct. 1, 2014</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/01/dining/hungry-city-old-tbilisi-garden-in-greenwich-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069043859">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/24/dining/hungry-city-abyssinia-in-harlem.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Abyssinia
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">African</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Harlem</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Frehiwot Reta, the chef and owner of Abyssinia, has long been known among New York’s Ethiopians as a master of injera, the round, sour flatbread, more than a foot in diameter and riddled with sinkholes, that is the base of every Ethiopian meal. She sold injera out of her Harlem apartment for a decade before opening this modest restaurant.



</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/09/24/dining/20140924-HUNGRY-slide-P7BT/20140924-HUNGRY-slide-P7BT-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2014-09-24T00:00:00">Sept. 24, 2014</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/24/dining/hungry-city-abyssinia-in-harlem.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>

<li id="story-id-1002207993303-33">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/24/dining/restaurant-review-sammys-roumanian-steakhouse-on-the-lower-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Sammy's Roumanian Steakhouse
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Steak Houses</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
What happens at Sammy’s doesn’t happen at other restaurants, and vice versa. The rest of the Lower East Side can obsess over filament lightbulbs; Sammy’s, Manhattan’s last surviving Roumanian-Jewish restaurant, will be ready when fluorescents make their triumphant return to fashion. It takes you back to 1975 with a little song, a little dance and even a little seltzer.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
PETE WELLS
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/09/24/dining/20140924-REST-slide-0C6Z/20140924-REST-slide-0C6Z-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2014-09-24T00:00:00">Sept. 24, 2014</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/24/dining/restaurant-review-sammys-roumanian-steakhouse-on-the-lower-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>
</li>
<li id="story-id-1248069043858">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/17/dining/restaurant-review-claudette-in-greenwich-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Claudette
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenwich Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Claudette serves Provençal cuisine with an intelligent twist. Rather than treating the region as if it were frozen in time and sealed off from the world, the kitchen casts a few glances at the North African immigrants who live and cook there.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/09/17/dining/20140917-REST-slide-JJVQ/20140917-REST-slide-JJVQ-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069043857">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/17/dining/hungry-city-taste-of-northern-china-in-chinatown.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Taste of Northern China
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chinatown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this small storefront under the Manhattan Bridge, the menu draws a wide map, from smoky, salty skewers with the flavors of Xinjiang, China’s Wild West; to gluten noodles with sesame paste and vinegar from Shaanxi; and beef noodle soup underscored by doubanjiang, in the Sichuan style.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/09/17/dining/20140917-HUNGRY-slide-D9ZY/20140917-HUNGRY-slide-D9ZY-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2014-09-17T00:00:00">Sept. 17, 2014</time>

<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/10/dining/restaurant-review-barchetta-in-chelsea.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Barchetta
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Italian, Seafood</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chelsea</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
There are encouraging nights when Barchetta seems like the ideal downtown seafood restaurant for people who really love the taste of fish. But when the kitchen loses its rhythm, Barchetta can seem mired among all the also-rans.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
PETE WELLS
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043855">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/10/dining/hungry-city-cafe-rue-dix-in-crown-heights-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Café Rue Dix
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">African, French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Crown Heights</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Café Rue Dix is a restaurant firmly of the neighborhood but cosmopolitan in outlook, mixing plates of French moules frites and Senegalese thiebou djeun, spinning Edith Piaf between griot rap and mbalax.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

Bar Primi

<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
One of several reasons to like Bar Primi, Andrew Carmellini’s new two-story restaurant on the corner of Second Street and the Bowery, is that there is almost nothing on the menu but appetizers and pasta. 
</p>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Moldova
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Russian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

<li id="story-id-1247467688998">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/20/dining/hungry-city-indian-road-cafe-in-inwood.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Indian Road Cafe
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Coffee Shops, New American, Sandwiches</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Inwood</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Wandering into Indian Road Cafe is like discovering a secret hideaway. In the culinary tug-of-war between innovation and familiarity, the chef Nicholas Wright-Bodine pulls tenaciously for Team Comfort.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Jeff Gordinier
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043849-34">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/13/dining/the-pain-and-pleasure-of-falling-in-love.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Bronx Beer Hall
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mediterranean</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Belmont</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This is a noble effort to coax some youthful energy into one of New York City’s legendary Italian-American neighborhoods. It’s a lovely place to loaf, nibbling on terrifically lip-searing chicken wings and sipping from a well-chilled selection of local brews.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Jeff Gordinier
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<li id="story-id-1248069043848">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/06/dining/restaurant-review-ivan-ramen.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Ivan Ramen
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Japanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Ivan Orkin, the Long Island-born chef who made his name cooking ramen in Tokyo, comes home with a restaurant that shows his breadth as a chef. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/08/06/dining/06REST2/06REST2-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069043847">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/06/dining/hungry-city-lumpia-shack-snackbar-in-the-west-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Lumpia Shack Snackbar
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Philippine</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">West Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Lumpia Shack Snackbar, Neil Syham, the chef, makes pretty but still potent versions of Filipino classics. There are just a few stools along the counter, which is too bad, because this is food best eaten on the spot.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/08/06/dining/20140806-HUNGRY-slide-VOPX/20140806-HUNGRY-slide-VOPX-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2014-08-06T00:00:00">Aug. 6, 2014</time>

<li id="story-id-1248069043845">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/30/dining/hungry-city-brooklyn-ball-factory-in-east-williamsburg.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Brooklyn Ball Factory
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
A Japanese comfort food and coffee shop in East Williamsburg with a rooftop deck. As for the brief menu, the ingredients are not extraordinary, the preparations not complicated. They don’t need to be.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069043846">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/30/dining/restaurant-review-russ-daughters-cafe.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Russ &amp; Daughters Cafe
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Eastern European</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The new Russ &amp; Daughters Cafe is modeled on the old Russ &amp; Daughters shop a few blocks away. But the cafe adds to, elaborates on and deviates from the store in many ways.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
PETE WELLS
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Racines NY 
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">TriBeCa</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Racines NY is a branch of one of Paris’s most influential wine bars. It has very little in common with the original, but it has virtues of its own.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043842">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/16/dining/restaurant-review-grindhaus-in-red-hook-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Grindhaus
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Red Hook</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Aaron Taber, the chef at Grindhaus, makes the kind of earnest, fashionably austere, handsomely arranged food that is signified on menus by sans-serif lists of ingredients, with no capital letters, verbs, articles or hint of how one thing might relate to the next. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/07/16/dining/20140716-REST-slide-R4TX/20140716-REST-slide-R4TX-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2014-07-16T00:00:00">July 16, 2014</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/16/dining/restaurant-review-grindhaus-in-red-hook-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>

<li id="story-id-1248069043841">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/16/dining/hungry-city-khao-kang-in-elmhurst-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Khao Kang
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Thai</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Elmhurst</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Khao Kang, there is no menu or wait service. Food is premade and presented cafeteria style. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043840">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/09/dining/uzbek-food-in-queens-and-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Chayhana Salom
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian, Russian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Sheepshead Bay</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The charming dining room is clean and bright behind a slightly grubby storefront. Food is served on formal china with glimmers of gilt.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043839">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/09/dining/uzbek-food-in-queens-and-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Uma's
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian, Russian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">The Rockaways</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Uma’s may be the only Uzbek restaurant in the United States (or the world) with surfboard parking, the Velvet Underground blaring and organic kale salad as an occasional special. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<li id="story-id-1248069043837-35">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/25/dining/hungry-city-baoburg-in-williamsburg-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Baoburg
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian, French, Spanish</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Baoburg’s idiosyncratic menu owes as much to classical European technique as it does to the cross-cultural upbringing of the chef, Suchanan Aksornnan.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043838">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/25/dining/restaurant-review-tavern-on-the-green.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Tavern on the Green
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-word-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="2">

<span class="visually-hidden"></span>

Satisfactory
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Mediterranean</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Upper West Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Compared with its last days before its death of insolvency in 2009 made it the subject of countless dry-eyed eulogies, Tavern on the Green is much, much improved.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells 
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<li id="story-id-1248069043836">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/18/dining/hungry-city-houdini-kitchen-laboratory-in-ridgewood-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Houdini Kitchen Laboratory
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Italian, Pizza</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Bushwick</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Houdini isn’t an of-the-moment speakeasy; it is simply, and wonderfully, a restaurant with good food and earnest intent that just happens to be in one of the coolest spaces in the city.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/06/18/dining/20140618-HUNGRY-slide-NZ39/20140618-HUNGRY-slide-NZ39-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Flinders Lane
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Australian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
There’s a genial ambiculturalism at play at this modern Australian restaurant, which shows clear affection for English tradition while reaching across the Indian Ocean and the South China Sea for more fervent flavors.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The first new restaurant Bobby Flay and his business partner, Laurence Kretchmer, have opened in New York City in a decade. The cooking at Gato is many things, often all at the same time, but it is rarely shy.
</p>

By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Spicy Lanka
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian, Indian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Jamaica Hills</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The menu for this Sri Lankan restaurant is terse and cryptic; best just to ask for recommendations, like pittu, squat columns of roasted rice flour, steamed with pandan leaves and adorned with icing-white curls of coconut.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Simone
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Upper East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
A classic Manhattan restaurant that seems to have emerged fully formed out of a time capsule sealed in the last century, the Simone has the kind of warmth that has become rare in Manhattan’s increasingly corporatized restaurant scene.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</a>

Narcissa 
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">

</li>

<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The chef John Fraser is known for his refined, thought-out vegetable tasting menus at Dovetail on the Upper West Side. His vegetable plates at Narcissa, in the Standard, East Village hotel, are more unbuttoned and generous.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Eim Khao Mun Kai
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Thai</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Elmhurst</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Eim Khao Mun Kai, the only dish on the menu is khao man gai, a sort of punkified cover version of Hainanese chicken rice. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069043828-36">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/21/dining/hungry-city-eim-khao-mun-kai-and-khao-man-gai-ny.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Khao Man Gai NY
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Thai</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Long Island City</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Emorn Henshaw, who grew up in northeast Thailand, spent two years perfecting her recipe for khao man gai (literally translated as chicken fat rice) before she and her husband, Eric, started serving it food markets, and now this location.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1191078231996">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/14/dining/restaurant-review-el-quinto-pino-in-chelsea.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
El Quinto Pino
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Spanish</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chelsea</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
A short “menu turistico” investigates a different region of the country every few months and the thirty seats in the dining room feel romantic, but not in an obvious way. It’s a room meant for talking.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Kung Fu Little Steamed Buns Ramen
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Clinton</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The specialty at this bare-bones shop is ramen in its original form, as it first came to Japan from China: la mian, or hand-pulled noodles, which are as much theater as comfort food. 
</p>

<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069043820-37">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/09/dining/hungry-city-lucky-luna-in-greenpoint-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Lucky Luna
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian, Chinese, Mexican</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenpoint</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Lucky Luna, a Mexican-Taiwanese restaurant, you'll find posole and tacos, congee and steamed bao buns. The excitement lies in unexpected details, like a house-made hot sauce that starts off Chinese, with a hit of vinegar, and finishes Mexican, with a swaggering heat.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<li id="story-id-1248069043818">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/02/dining/restaurant-review-the-peacock-and-the-shakespeare-in-midtown.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Peacock
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">English</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown South</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The William, a boutique hotel, offers two upholstered cocktail lounges and two distinct places to eat reformed English cooking. Upstairs is the Peacock, a civilized, grown-up restaurant.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/04/02/dining/20140402-REST-slide-EB6H/20140402-REST-slide-EB6H-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2014-04-01T13:58:44">April 1, 2014</time>

</li>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

Pete Wells

<li id="story-id-1248069043798">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/05/dining/hungry-city-rusty-mackerel-in-hudson-heights.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Rusty Mackerel
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mediterranean, New American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Washington Heights</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At this narrow, cheerful restaurant in the quiet northwestern corner of Washington Heights, the flavors are mainly Mediterranean, with the occasional high-concept dish, like a burger that’s a cross between a Dominican chimi and a British butty. The chef and owner, James Moran, grew up in the neighborhood. His first job was as a delivery boy for Frank’s Market, around the corner; the owners, who gave him his nickname, Mac, are now his business partners. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/03/05/dining/05HUNGRY_395/05HUNGRY_395-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
