<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/29/dining/hungry-city-yun-nan-flavour-garden-in-sunset-park-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Yun Nan Flavour Garden 
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Borough Park</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Yun Nan Flavour Garden, formerly Yun Nan Flavour Snack, features the hard-to-find crossing-the bridge-noodles alongside its greatest hits: perfect dumplings, lucid soups and house-made rice noodles with bounce and bite.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/01/29/dining/29HUNGRY_395/29HUNGRY_395-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2014-01-29T00:00:00">Jan. 29, 2014</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/29/dining/hungry-city-yun-nan-flavour-garden-in-sunset-park-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>
</li>
<li id="story-id-1248069043687">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/22/dining/restaurant-review-han-dynasty-in-the-east-village-and-hirohisa-in-soho.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Han Dynasty
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-word-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="2">

<span class="visually-hidden"></span>

Satisfactory
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Han Chiang’s chain of Sichuan restaurants has been so popular in and around Philadelphia that Mr. Chiang plans to open 100 locations around the country. There are quite a few towns where this would be great news, but Manhattan has far better Sichuan kitchens.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/01/22/dining/20140122-REST-slide-LFBS/20140122-REST-slide-LFBS-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2014-01-22T00:00:00">Jan. 22, 2014</time>

<li id="story-id-1248069043682">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/22/dining/restaurant-review-han-dynasty-in-the-east-village-and-hirohisa-in-soho.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Hirohisa
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">SoHo</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Hirohisa is a kappo-style restaurant, a form of Japanese dining in which the chef makes both hot and cold dishes behind a counter.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/01/22/dining/20140122-REST-slide-R007/20140122-REST-slide-R007-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2014-01-22T00:00:00">Jan. 22, 2014</time>

<li id="story-id-1248069043672">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/22/dining/hungry-city-the-east-pole-on-the-upper-east-side.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The East Pole
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, English</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Upper East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The East Pole is the uptown spinoff of the vaguely British fashion-crowd canteen the Fat Radish, on the Lower East Side. The loveliest dishes revolve around vegetables. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Bistro at Villard Michel Richard
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-word-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="1">

<span class="visually-hidden"></span>

Fair
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown East</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Villard Michel Richard, the latest restaurant to dance among the frescoes and marble pillars of the Villard mansion in Midtown, could be taken as homage to awful hotel dining rooms.
</p>

By
<span class="author-name">

Korchma Taras Bulba
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">

<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

Pete Wells

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Onomea
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">




<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

<li id="story-id-1248069043787">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/11/dining/reviews/hungry-city-larb-ubol-in-hells-kitchen.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Larb Ubol
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Thai</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown West</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
To a passer-by, there is little to distinguish Larb Ubol from the 30 or so pad-Thai joints that are its neighbors in Hell’s Kitchen. But the chef and owner, Ratchanee Sumpatboon, does not cook the Thai food most Americans know. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069043670">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/11/dining/reviews/restaurant-review-sushi-nakazawa-in-the-west-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Sushi Nakazawa
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="5">

<span class="visually-hidden">4.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese, Sushi</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">West Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The moment-to-moment joys of eating one mouthful of sushi after another can merge into a blur of fish bliss. But almost everything Daisuke Nakazawa cups in his hands and places in front of you is an event on its own.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2013/12/11/dining/11REST_395/11REST_395-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2013-12-11T00:00:00">Dec. 11, 2013</time>

</li>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Charlie Bird
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Italian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">SoHo</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Charlie Bird has the slightly-too-crowded and slightly-too-loud spirit that keeps people living in New York, even while they gripe about it. But at its best it masters an eager-to-please Italian mode that leans heavily on cheese, salt and crunch.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells

<li id="story-id-1248069043776">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Quality Italian
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Italian, Steak Houses</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
A kind of clone of Quality Meats, a block away, with some Italian-American food grafted on for good measure, it is the restaurant that finally answers the question “What if we set lobster fra diavolo on fire?”
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

<div class="wide-thumb">

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2013-11-06T00:00:00">Nov. 6, 2013</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/06/dining/reviews/restaurant-review-quality-italian-in-midtown.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Hearth
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Italian, New American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
When he opened Hearth in 2003, Marco Canora, its chef, set out to adapt the transparency of Tuscan cooking to his own region and time of year. Mr. Canora gets few points for the originality of his vision, but for his fidelity to it, his score is off the charts. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Umami Burger
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Hamburgers</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenwich Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Adam Fleischman devised the Umami burger recipe in his home kitchen in Los Angeles in a single day. The result is a good, occasionally exceptional burger, which for all the umami bluster isn’t notably different from other good burgers around town.

Whiskey Soda Lounge NY

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Whiskey Soda Lounge Ny serves as a way station where people can nosh and drink and watch Muay Thai highlight reels while waiting for a table at Pok Pok Ny down the street. It is more than that, though. It’s also a gallery of Thailand’s bar snacks.

Pete Wells

<li id="story-id-1248069043613">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/18/dining/reviews/hungry-city-distilled-in-tribeca.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Distilled
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">TriBeCa</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The mission statement that preceded a meal (“We are an American public house”) was slightly coy about the restaurant’s ambitions. There are wings, onion rings and ribs, but they are elevated by unexpected spices and technical flourishes. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Glasserie
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mediterranean</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenpoint</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Glasserie’s chef, Sara Kramer, who spent time in the Marlow &amp; Sons empire, diverges from the New Brooklyn model by reaching back to the Levantine spices of her Israeli heritage to create dishes that are at once artful and effortless. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Armani Ristorante Fifth Avenue
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Italian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown East</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Armani Ristorante, on the third floor of the Armani store on Fifth Avenue, looks a little odd, but when the menu is at its best, it takes its cues from the understated style of Milanese cuisine.
</p>

By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Taste of Persia NYC
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Middle Eastern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Flatiron</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Taste of Persia NYC, a takeout counter tucked into a utilitarian pizzeria on 18th Street, Saeed Pourkay serves his justly fabled ash reshteh, a wondrous, wintry, outrageously thick Persian soup, along with rustic stews that have been simmered for hours. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Los Tacos No. 1
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican, Tex-Mex</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chelsea</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Hatched by three entrepreneurial gents from the West (two from California, one from northern Mexico), Los Tacos No. 1 is more or less engineered to serve as an oasis for all those West Coast transplants who are constantly complaining about the dubious quality of tacos in New York City.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Jeff Gordinier
</span>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Tres Carnes
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican, Tex-Mex</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Flatiron</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
It's an alluringly simple idea: Take some Lone Star-quality barbecue and put it into tacos and burritos. You’ll encounter an abundance of sides and fillings as you make your way down the Chipotle-style assembly line.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">

Jeff Gordinier

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Costata
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Michael White returns to the address in SoHo where he made his name, when it was called Fiamma. Now he is an owner and the restaurant is a steakhouse, and the bone-in rib-eye for two, called the Costata, is a reason for this restaurant to exist all by itself. 
</p>

Pete Wells

Oda House
</h2>

<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/31/dining/reviews/restaurant-review-abc-cocina-in-manhattan.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
ABC Cocina
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Latin American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Flatiron</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The menu, a collaboration of Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Dan Kluger, rummages through the cupboards of Spanish-speaking countries. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2013/07/31/dining/31REST_SPAN/31REST_SPAN-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Feast
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The concept behind Feast is to find the midpoint between the ever more esoteric tasting menus that have proliferated around town and the humble satisfactions of a smorgasbord.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Mamak House
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Malaysian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Flushing</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Mamak House focuses on the cooking of the Mamak community — Malaysians with Indian Muslim roots — on the Malaysian island of Penang. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Nightingale 9
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Vietnamese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Carroll Gardens</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The chef, Robert Newton — who was born in Arkansas and runs the Southern restaurant Seersucker a few doors down — borrows flavors across a distance, finding resonances between the cooking of Vietnam and that of his heritage. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069043612">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/26/dining/reviews/hungry-city-hunan-manor-in-midtown.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Hunan Manor
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Murray Hill</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The menu at Hunan Manor includes a few Sichuan classics, but mostly you will find unmitigated heat of Hunan dishes, without the tempering sweetness or the pins and needles along the tongue that come with Sichuan cuisine. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2013/06/26/dining/26HUNGRY_SPAN/26HUNGRY_SPAN-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069043555">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/26/dining/reviews/restaurant-review-lafayette-in-noho.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Lafayette
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">NoHo</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Lafayette is like a junior Eataly for Francophiles. As for the food, there are salads and charcuterie and oysters and shoestring fries. Almost all of it is worthy, but very little seduces you.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2013/06/26/dining/26REST1_SPAN/26REST1-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1247466984128">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/19/dining/reviews/restaurant-review-kajitsu-in-murray-hill.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Kajitsu
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese, Sushi</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Murray Hill</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Kajitsu practices an animal-free cooking tradition called shojin-ryori that was developed in Zen Buddhist monasteries over many centuries. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

</a>

<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/12/dining/reviews/restaurant-review-montmartre-in-chelsea.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Montmartre 
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian, French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chelsea</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The pot au pho and other French-Asian fusion dishes at Montmartre often have more conviction than the straight-up French food of many other New York bistros.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2013/06/12/dining/12REST_SPAN/12REST_SPAN-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2013-06-12T00:00:00">June 12, 2013</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">

<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/12/dining/reviews/restaurant-review-montmartre-in-chelsea.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Maison Premiere
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Seafood</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
When Maison Premiere first opened in Williamsburg, it was primarily a bar, serving little more than absinthe and oysters. But now a proper kitchen has been built in the basement and the menu expanded.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Salvation Taco
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-word-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="2">

<span class="visually-hidden"></span>

Satisfactory
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Murray Hill</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This jammed and noisy restaurant inside the Pod, a new hotel in Murray Hill, offers small tacos in tortillas slightly bigger than an English muffin. 
</p>

By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Taqueria Tlaxcalli
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Parkchester</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The menu includes tacos, tortas, gorditas, sopes and molcajetes, all prepared with fidelity to the spirit of Mexico City’s taquerias.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043565">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/22/dining/reviews/hungry-city-bunker-in-ridgewood-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Bunker
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Vietnamese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Ridgewood</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This scuffed yellow storefront on the desolate eastern edge of Ridgewood, Queens, is not where you expect to find a chef who once cooked at Eleven Madison Park, and who is now making some of the best Vietnamese street-style food in New York City.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

Caravaggio
</h2>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Prospect
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Fort Greene</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
As conceived by Annika Loureiro, the pastry chef, desserts at Prospect are an extension, and possibly the fullest realization, of the themes and intent of the preceding meal. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan

<li id="story-id-1248069042922">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/01/dining/reviews/hungry-city-salt-fat-in-sunnyside-queens.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Salt &amp; Fat
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Asian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Sunnyside</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Daniel Yi, the chef and owner of Salt &amp; Fat, describes his cooking as New American, and in a sense it is exactly, exultingly that — the food of the new America, in which immigrants companionably raid one another’s larders.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2013/05/01/dining/1HUNGRY_SPAN/31HUNGRY_SPAN-blog225.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">

<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/24/dining/reviews/restaurant-review-randazzos-clam-bar-in-sheepshead-bay.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Randazzo's Clam Bar
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Italian, Seafood</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Sheepshead Bay</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The dark, concentrated, oregano-accented tomato sauce ladled on hot or chilled lobster, fried shrimp, steamed mussels, scungilli or fried calamari is so central to Randazzo’s mission that some customers never look beyond it.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The Library at the Public
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
There is nothing glib about the food at The Library at the Public, a crepuscular attic of a restaurant chiseled from the upper recesses of the lobby at the Public Theater.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Xixa
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Xixa, which opened in December in South Williamsburg, Mexico is merely a starting point for a kind of culinary free association that can be borderline loco or brilliant, sometimes both at once. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

</h2>

<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">New American</li>

<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown East</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Of Danny Meyer’s two restaurants on the ground floor of the Museum of Modern Art, the casual Bar Room is more fun, but the Dining Room has the view of the sculpture garden and a dining experience that goes from one delight to another. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Chez Sardine
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>

<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">West Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Chez Sardine offers the kind of izakaya where a bite-size piece of hamachi sushi is crunchy with fried pork rinds, and where sashimi is slipped in among a stack of flapjacks.
</p>

By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/13/dining/reviews/hungry-city-mayfield-in-crown-heights-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Mayfield
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Crown Heights</li>

</ul>

By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

The Marrow
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

</h2>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Arlington Club
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Steak Houses</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Upper East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
A self-described steakhouse that can be experienced in any number of ways. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Zizi Limona
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mediterranean, Middle Eastern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Zizi Limona, which opened in Williamsburg in September, cultivates an air of unhurry, and as for the name, it is happy nonsense, invented by the owners, veterans of Middle Eastern establishments in Manhattan who wanted to be free of culinary or geographic limitation.
</p>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>

<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Upper East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Heavily influenced by the Persian cuisine that was brought to the subcontinent by the Mogul emperors, the cooking of North India still has an imperial lavishness when cooked with care and consideration for ingredients, as it is at Moti Mahal Delux.

By

Pete Wells

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Ducks Eatery
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Asian, Barbecue</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
M. Wells Dinette
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>

<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">French</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Long Island City</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This reprise of M. Wells, which operated in a tin-can diner for just over a year, is not open for dinner and seems to have scaled back the portions ever so slightly for daytime eating.

Rustic L.E.S.
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
'21' Club
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-word-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="2">

<span class="visually-hidden"></span>

Satisfactory
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
There are only a few things at “21” that one can order with any anticipation: the famous chicken hash, the “21” burger and the coconut cake, topped with a beehive of white meringue and toasted coconut. But to judge “21” as a restaurant is to miss the point of the place.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069043301">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/24/dining/reviews/hungry-city-blue-collar-and-lake-trout-in-williamsburg.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Blue Collar
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Hamburgers</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Blue Collar is a sunny counter-service-only spot, with red chairs and round white tables anchored by bottles of ketchup and mustard. Burgers, built in the In-N-Out Californian style, start at $4, single and unadorned, and top out at $6.25 for a double with cheese, which is the one you want. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043322-49">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Lake Trout
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Seafood</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Williamsburg</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Lake Trout’s name refers to a working-class Baltimore specialty that is neither lake in origin nor trout. It consists of whiting, a salt-water bottom-feeder, deep fried and flung on white bread.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Phayul 
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Tibetan</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Jackson Heights</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At Phayul, whose name means fatherland in Tibetan, the food is lively and rugged, true to what you might find in the alpine villages of Kham and on the austere steppe of Amdo. 
</p>

By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>

<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Southern</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Southern fried chicken is the mission at Bobwhite Lunch &amp; Supper Counter, a small, no-fuss storefront in Alphabet City, whose owner and chef, Keedick Coulter, hails from Roanoke, Va.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/09/19/dining/19HUNGRY_SPAN/19HUNGRY_SPAN-sfSpan.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069043235">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/15/dining/reviews/biang-nyc-restaurant-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Biang!
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Flushing</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Biang! is a collaboration between David Shi and his son, Jason Wang, both natives of the ancient imperial city of Xi’an in central China. The merged sensibilities result in a place where Chinese grandparents can sit down next to young people who may not know the original recipes but can recognize great flavors and a very good deal when they see them. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>

Grey Lady
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Seafood</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The mood is blithe at Grey Lady, whose name salutes befogged Nantucket, where the restaurant’s owners summered when young. Loiterers at the long marble-topped bar have the air of preppy surfers who will be fox-hunting come fall. This is the seafood shack by way of Ralph Lauren. 
</p>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Nicoletta
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-word-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="1">

<span class="visually-hidden"></span>

Fair
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Italian, Pizza</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Nicoletta’s pizzas are not quite deep dish, but they are heading in that direction. The crust is as strong as epoxy, and are piled up with an abundance of toppings that would buckle an ordinary pie.

<li id="story-id-1248069043211">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/01/dining/reviews/foragers-city-table-in-chelsea-restaurant-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Foragers City Table
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American, Asian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Chelsea</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Foragers City Table, which opened in April, is an annex to the boutique market Foragers City Grocer. Both are offshoots of Foragers Market in Dumbo, Brooklyn, which subscribes to the credo of local sourcing and sustainability. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">

Mexicocina
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">

<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Mexican</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">North New York</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Mile End Sandwich
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Deli, Sandwiches</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">NoHo</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Mile End Sandwich, the Manhattan offshoot of Mile End deli in Brooklyn, looks more like a Helmut Lang boutique than an appetizing shop. The roster of sandwiches, more expansive than in Brooklyn, reads like a family album of the Jewish diaspora.
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043079">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Hot Kitchen
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The word “hot” does not adequately convey the seemingly infinite shades of heat that ripple through this small, unpretentious Sichuanese restaurant, a minimalist canteen in whitewashed brick and red beams that is closer in geography and spirit to N.Y.U. than Chinatown. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan

<li id="story-id-1248069043214">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/27/dining/reviews/pok-pok-ny-brooklyn-restaurant-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Pok Pok Ny
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Thai</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Columbia Street Waterfront District</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Altered perceptions come free with the price of dinner at Pok Pok Ny, opened by the chef Andy Ricker, of Portland, Ore. Mr. Ricker’s specialty is recreating the food of northern Thailand, which has been hard to find in New York City. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells 
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043275">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/27/dining/reviews/yopparai-a-sake-bar-on-the-lower-east-side-serves-just-30-hungry-city.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Yopparai
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Lower East Side</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Everything at Yopparai is designed to unknot the mind: cushioned benches for two in lieu of bar stools; sake poured in doll-size cups, forcing you to sip; comforting small plates and rustic snacks; a cloudy undertow of jazz. At this modest sake bar, you eat the way you drink, in tiny mouthfuls. And so the hours drift. You will not notice. 

</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/06/27/dining/27HUNGRY_SPAN/27HUNGRY_SPAN-sfSpan.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2012-06-27T00:00:00">June 27, 2012</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/27/dining/reviews/yopparai-a-sake-bar-on-the-lower-east-side-serves-just-30-hungry-city.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

<li>
<a class="reserve-table" href="http://www.opentable.com/single.aspx?ref=4201&amp;rid=85645" target="_blank" title="Reserve a Table">Reserve a Table</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>

<li id="story-id-1248069043077">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/20/dining/reviews/battersby-restaurant-thrives-on-smith-street-in-cobble-hill-brooklyn-hungry-city.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Battersby
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">New American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Cobble Hill</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
At its best, the food at Battersby is thoughtful, poised, occasionally revelatory. The menu of about a dozen dishes changes as often as three times a week. Best to submit to the five- or seven-course tasting, which the chefs improvise on the spot, for half what you might pay across the river. This is fine dining in hipster’s clothing: the new new Brooklyn.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/06/20/dining/20HUNGRY2_SPAN/20HUNGRY2-sfSpan.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2012-06-20T00:00:00">June 20, 2012</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/20/dining/reviews/battersby-restaurant-thrives-on-smith-street-in-cobble-hill-brooklyn-hungry-city.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

<a class="reserve-table" href="http://www.opentable.com/single.aspx?ref=4201&amp;rid=152311" target="_blank" title="Reserve a Table">Reserve a Table</a>

</ul>
</footer>
</article>
</li>
<li id="story-id-1248069043274">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/20/dining/reviews/the-nomad-in-new-york.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
The NoMad
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="4">

<span class="visually-hidden">3.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">American</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">NoMad</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
The NoMad in the NoMad Hotel is operated by the same duo who run Eleven Madison Park in New York, and with this restaurant, they have done something rather novel and wonderful.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/06/20/dining/20REST1_SPAN/20JPREST1-sfSpan.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Hakkasan New York
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese, Dim Sum</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Clinton</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This multimillion-dollar exercise in Orientalism off Times Square is the seventh in a global chain started in London.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells 
</span>
</p>

<li id="story-id-1248069043249">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/06/dining/reviews/restaurant-review-catch-in-meatpacking-district.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Catch
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Seafood</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">West Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Can you eat well at a restaurant with 260 seats, bored hostesses, incoherent decor and a party-platter-friendly menu primed for franchising? Confoundingly, yes. Much of the menu reads like a catalogue: you may order crab by the pound, seafood by the tower, oysters and Krug as a gift set, and mix-and-match fishes and sauces.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/06/06/dining/06HUNGRY1_SPAN/06HUNGRY1_SPAN-sfSpan-v2.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2012-06-06T00:00:00">June 6, 2012</time>
<ul class="story-action-menu">
<li>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/06/dining/reviews/restaurant-review-catch-in-meatpacking-district.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">Read Review</a>
</li>

<li>
<a class="reserve-table" href="http://www.opentable.com/single.aspx?ref=4201&amp;rid=70204" target="_blank" title="Reserve a Table">Reserve a Table</a>
</li>

</ul>
</footer>

<li id="story-id-1248069043185">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/06/dining/reviews/restaurant-review-neta-in-greenwich-village.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Neta
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Japanese, Sushi</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenwich Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
One of the two chefs who founded Neta, Nick Kim, was head chef at Masa. His partner, Jimmy Lau, was head chef at Bar Masa, where among other duties he was in charge of international fish buying. But sushi purists looking for hard-to-obtain Japanese seafood species are likely to be disappointed. Instead, Neta has compensatory pleasures, like the quality of its rice, the exceptional vegetable sushi and above all the small plates. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells 
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/06/06/dining/06REST_SPAN/06REST_SPAN-sfSpan.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->
<footer class="story-footer">
<time class="dateline" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2012-06-06T00:00:00">June 6, 2012</time>

</li>

<a class="reserve-table" href="http://www.opentable.com/single.aspx?ref=4201&amp;rid=77899" target="_blank" title="Reserve a Table">Reserve a Table</a>

<li id="story-id-1248069043155-52">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/30/dining/reviews/bar-corvo-in-crown-heights-brooklyn.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Bar Corvo
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Italian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Prospect Heights</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Bar Corvo is sleeker than its shabby-chic older sister, Al di Là’, but less daring in the kitchen. It is not quite a destination restaurant, just the restaurant everybody wants in their neighborhood. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">

</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

</a>
</div><!-- close story-body -->

<li id="story-id-1248069043232">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/23/dining/reviews/restaurant-review-anjappar-in-murray-hill.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Anjappar
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Indian</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Kips Bay</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Chettinadu cuisine, the specialty of this New York franchise of a Chennai-based chain, is surprisingly meat-centric, considering its origins in vegetarian-dominated southern India.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

</h2>

<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Miss Lily’s Bakeshop &amp; Melvin’s Juice Box
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Caribbean</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Greenwich Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
A cheerful spot that’s part diner, part beachfront snack shack: a handful of tables, some bar stools at a counter, a pair of benches set outside.
</p>

By
<span class="author-name">

606 R &amp; D

<li id="story-id-1248069043043">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/02/dining/reviews/cafe-china-in-midtown.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Cafe China
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3.5">

<span class="visually-hidden">2.0 stars</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i><i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Chinese</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Midtown South</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
This quaint, demure restaurant serves uncompromising Sichuan food that can stand with Manhattan’s best. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Pete Wells
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
David's Brisket House
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Deli</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Bedford-Stuyvesant</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
For decades, this Brooklyn classic has been turning out the sassiest pastrami, sultriest brisket and lean, mean corned beef sandwiches.
</p>

By
<span class="author-name">
Betsy Andrews
</span>

<li id="story-id-1248069043225">
<article class="story theme-summary " itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Restaurant">
<div class="story-body">
<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/25/dining/reviews/la-churreria-nyc-restaurant-review.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Socarrat
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Bakery/Baked Goods, Desserts, Spanish</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Nolita</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Churros are the supermodels of the doughnut world: long, skinny and vaguely extraterrestrial. At La Churreria, they are moist inside yet dry to the touch, crisp and fluffy and chewy all at once; dunk them in the accompanying hot chocolate, which is served in a coffee cup and so dark and thick it almost counts as a pudding.
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</div><!-- close story-meta -->

<div class="wide-thumb">
<img role="presentation" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2012/04/25/dining/25BRIEF1_SPAN/25BRIEF1-sfSpan.jpg" alt="" itemprop="thumbnailUrl">
</div><!-- close wide-thumb -->

<a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/29/dining/reviews/ngams-modern-thai-food-stays-true-to-traditional-flavors.html?rref=collection%2Fcollection%2Frestaurant-guide">
<div class="story-meta">
<h2 class="headline" itemprop="headline">
Ngam
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

<li class="critics-pick">
<i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
<span class="critics-pick-label">NYT Critic’s Pick</span>
</li>



<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Thai</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">East Village</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">
Hong Thaimee, a native of Thailand who has cooked for the royal family there, reinterprets Thai cuisine as modern comfort food. 
</p>

<p class="byline" itemprop="author">
By
<span class="author-name">
Ligaya Mishan
</span>
</p>

</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

Shake Shack
</h2>
<ul class="review-meta-menu">


<li class="critic-star-rating" itemprop="reviewRating" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Rating">
<meta itemprop="worstRating" content="0">
<meta itemprop="bestRating" content="5">
<meta itemprop="ratingValue" content="3">

<span class="visually-hidden">1 star</span>

<i class="icon sprite-icon star-icon"></i>
</li>


<li itemprop="servesCuisine">Fast Food, Hamburgers, Hot Dogs</li>


<li itemprop="priceRange">$</li>


<li itemprop="addressLocality" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">Downtown Brooklyn</li>

</ul>
<p class="summary" itemprop="description">

</p>

Pete Wells
</span>
